headline: ‘Capernaum’ Review: A Heartbreaking and Defiant Look at a Boy’s Life in Beirut
summary_short: Like a Charles Dickens hero, Zain makes his way through a city where cruelty and injustice threaten to overwhelm kindness and decency.

headline: ‘Ghostbox Cowboy’ Review: An Absurd Entrepreneur Is Lost in Asia
summary_short: John Maringouin directs a dryly funny dissection of entrepreneurial absurdism bleeding into existential and metaphysical despair.

display_title: Lots of Kids, a Monkey and a Castle
headline: ‘Lots of Kids, a Monkey and a Castle’ Review: She Wanted Three Things in Life
summary_short: The Spanish actor Gustavo Salmerón stitches together an affectionate, frank portrait of his indomitable mother in this family documentary.

headline: ‘Dead Souls’ Review: Forgotten Victims of Mao’s Camps Speak
summary_short: More than eight hours long and harrowing to watch, Wang Bing’s “Dead Souls” is a necessary look at China’s brutal re-education camps for “rightists.”

headline: ‘The House That Jack Built’ Review: Sick, Violent and a Total Bore
summary_short: Matt Dillon may play a serial killer in Lars von Trier’s latest movie, but its real subject seems to be its director.

headline: ‘The Mule’ Review: Clint Eastwood’s Very Strange Drug Trip
summary_short: In his latest exploration of modern masculinity, the veteran filmmaker plays an unlikely courier for a cartel who finds redemption. It’s a rough ride.

headline: ‘Martyr’ Review: Tight Bonds and Isolation in Beirut
summary_short: Set in a poor section of the city, Mazen Khaled’s film captures the numbness, grief and rage that come out of strife.

headline: ‘Mortal Engines’ Review: London Becomes a Death Star on Wheels
summary_short: To the extent that “Mortal Engines” resembles anything, it’s other movies, which it plunders with a landfill-diving zeal that suits the surviving populace.

headline: ‘Never-Ending Man: Hayao Miyazaki’ Review: Animation Giant, Retired and Restless
summary_short: The director of animated classics like “Spirited Away” reflects on his career in this documentary.

headline: ‘That Way Madness Lies …’ Review: A Terrifying True Story, Ordinarily Told
summary_short: The director Sandra Luckow chronicles her brother’s mental illness. If this is a subject matter that has touched your life, you ought to see this movie.

headline: ‘Bird Box’ Review: The End of the World Is Riveting. Sometimes.
summary_short: Sandra Bullock, Sarah Paulson and a strong cast appear in this sci-fi thriller adapted from a novel by Josh Malerman.

headline: ‘If Beale Street Could Talk’ Review: Trusting Love in a World Ruled by Hate
summary_short: The couple in this adaptation of James Baldwin’s novel are loving while black, an existential truth that is turned into a nightmare.

headline: ‘Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse’ Review: A Fresh Take on a Venerable Hero
summary_short: This lively, diverse comic-book movie brings some fun to a genre that often takes itself too seriously.

headline: ‘The World Is Yours’ Review: Isabelle Adjani Revitalizes the Comic Caper
summary_short: Adjani’s turn as a flamboyant con artist sends up her own aloof image in this fun and sophisticated comic caper from Romain Gavras.

headline: ‘Vox Lux’ Review: An Apocalyptic Star Is Born
summary_short: In Brady Corbet’s new movie, Natalie Portman plays a pop star, a teenage victim of a mass shooting who has grown up to become a 21st-century brand.

headline: ‘The Party’s Just Beginning’ Review: Loss and Love in Inverness
summary_short: The actress Karen Gillan gets glum to play a depressed young woman in her feature directorial debut.

display_title: Divide and Conquer: The Story of Roger Ailes
headline: ‘Divide and Conquer: The Story of Roger Ailes’ Review: Portrait of a News Exec
summary_short: Alexis Bloom’s film gives viewers a credible sense of Ailes’s psychology through the testimony of peers and co-workers who witnessed his ruthlessness firsthand.

headline: ‘Mary Queen of Scots’ Review: Sexy, Spirited and Almost Convincing
summary_short: Saoirse Ronan is the doomed Scottish queen, and Margot Robbie is her cousin Elizabeth I in this vigorously revisionist historical drama.

headline: ‘Asher’ Review: An Aging Hit Man Finds Love
summary_short: Ron Perlman and Famke Janssen star in this film that finds a hired killer dealing with his own mortality.

headline: ‘Bitter Melon’ Review: Filipino-American Brothers Go Home for the Holidays
summary_short: This film by H.P. Mendoza shows a willingness to roil a holiday movie formula, but also a wobbly grasp of tone.

headline: ‘Swimming With Men’ Review: An Amiable Look at Aging Bodies
summary_short: In this British comedy, a middle-aged accountant finds peace through synchronized swimming.

headline: ‘The Great Pretender’ Review: Tedious Love Affairs in Artsy Brooklyn
summary_short: In Nathan Silver’s new film, American bros break the hearts of beautiful Frenchwomen. Realism or wishful thinking?

headline: ‘Amazing Grace’ Review: Aretha Franklin Is Glorious in a Rousing Concert Film
summary_short: The film Aretha Franklin didn’t want you to see arrives in theaters. It captures an incandescent Queen of Soul recording her 1972 live album.

headline: ‘Ben Is Back’ Review: A Mother and Son Face the Horrors of Addiction
summary_short: Strong performances by Lucas Hedges and Julia Roberts anchor this somber, scary family drama.

headline: Review: ‘Dumplin’’ Shares an Ordinary Girl’s Truth
summary_short: Danielle Macdonald stars in this uninspired adaptation of Julie Murphy’s young adult novel about a big girl’s struggle against small minds.

headline: ‘Tyrel’ Review: Drowning in a Whirlpool of Drunken Dudes
summary_short: Sebastián Silva’s film is a racially charged cringe comedy-drama about being stuck with a group of guys you barely know.

headline: ‘The Charmer’ Review: Desperate Man Seeks Willing Lover. Watch Out.
summary_short: This Danish thriller is the first feature from the writer and director Milad Alami. Details are revealed in “nail-biting” style, our critic writes.

headline: ‘Head Full of Honey’ Review: Alzheimer’s Gets the Wacky Grandpa Treatment
summary_short: Nick Nolte, Matt Dillon and Emily Mortimer star in this tonally disheveled, occasionally offensive movie.

headline: ‘Happy as Lazzaro’ Review: This Modern Fairy Tale Is an Instant Classic
summary_short: A man’s journey from the feudal countryside to the modern city has the urgency of a news bulletin. A.O. Scott calls it one of the year’s best films.

headline: ‘United Skates’ Review: A Rallying Cry for Black Roller Skating Culture
summary_short: Dyana Winkler and Tina Brown’s elegiac, euphoric documentary is a passion project in the best sense of the word.

headline: ‘Mirai’ Review: A Charming Animated Trip Into a Family’s Past
summary_short: The birth of a sibling can feel like the end of the world to a child, but for a little boy named Kun, envy turns to wonder as a new universe opens up.

headline: ‘Sicilian Ghost Story’ Review: Fairy-Tale Love Meets Real-Life Crime
summary_short: Flipping from bucolic to brutal with distressing ease, this beautifully realized movie views a Mafia kidnapping through the prism of first love.

display_title: Electro-Pythagorus: A Portrait of Martin Bartlett
headline: ‘Electro-Pythagorus’ Review: An Experimental Look at an Innovator
summary_short: Luke Fowler imbues this film about the electronic musician Martin Bartlett with a numinous quality reflective of the subject’s work and aesthetic.

headline: ‘The Possession of Hannah Grace’ Review: A Demon Makes for a Noisy Corpse
summary_short: This horror film from Diederik Van Rooijen establishes a tense mood by alternating between ear-shattering demonism and extended periods of suspenseful silence.

headline: ‘Anna and the Apocalypse’ Review: They Sing, Dance and Get Eaten
summary_short: This zombie musical, about a Scottish high school student, feels more like a sketch than a developed movie.

headline: ‘DriverX’ Review: Behind the Wheel and Ready for Anything
summary_short: In this film, starring Patrick Fabian, a new driver for a rideshare company experiences dark nights of the soul.

headline: ‘People’s Republic of Desire’ Review: A Virtual Craze Makes Actual Cash
summary_short: The documentary looks at live-streaming culture in China, where show hosts shill for money, and fans willingly pay up.

headline: ‘The Mercy’ Review: Sailing Around the World, or Maybe Not
summary_short: Colin Firth’s touching performance as the flawed British sailor Donald Crowhurst lends soul to James Marsh’s starchy English tragedy.

headline: ‘Song of Back and Neck’ Review: A Painful Comedy About Pain
summary_short: In the film, Paul Lieberstein plays a man who just needs to learn to scream. Viewers will feel his pain.

headline: ‘Elliot: The Littlest Reindeer’ Review: A Miniature Horse Hoofs His Way to the Top
summary_short: Elliot has trained patiently to be “Santa’s first non-reindeer reindeer.” Moviegoing audiences might not show the same patience.

headline: ‘Mowgli: Legend of the Jungle’ Review: A Boy and His Digitized Wolves
summary_short: This film version of Rudyard Kipling’s story collection has a lot more dirt, blood and death in it than other adaptations.

headline: ‘Rams’ Review: The Man Who Made Our Machines Beautiful
summary_short: Easy-to-use products with clean lines started with Dieter Rams. Meet the German designer in this elegant new documentary.

headline: ‘Shoplifters’ Review: A Family That Steals Together, Stays Together
summary_short: In this beautifully felt drama, the Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda dives into the mess of life with a story about a family on the ragged edge.

headline: ‘Becoming Astrid’ Review: A Children’s Author Finds Her Voice
summary_short: This biopic of the Swedish writer of the “Pippi Longstocking” series hits familiar beats, but its performances are pitch perfect.

headline: ‘Inquiring Nuns’ Review: A Simple Question Yields Many Profound Answers
summary_short: In this newly restored 1968 documentary, two nuns ask a variety of passers-by in Chicago: “Are you happy?”

headline: ‘Invisible Hands’ Review: The Children Fueling Global Capitalism
summary_short: Shraysi Tandon’s dense investigative documentary jumps into the murky and shameful world of child trafficking and forced labor.

headline: ‘Family in Transition’ Review: A Parent Prepares for Change
summary_short: The documentary tells the story of Amit Tsuk, who comes out as transgender, and the effect it has on the family.

headline: ‘Write When You Get Work’ Review: Backstreet Boy Seeks Uptown Girl
summary_short: A petty thief stalks his former lover in Stacy Cochran’s messy, maddening New York City romance.

headline: ‘The Favourite’ Review: Scheming for Power in a Kinky Palace Triangle
summary_short: Yorgos Lanthimos’s new film, starring Olivia Colman, Emma Stone and Rachel Weisz, turns 18th-century royal intrigue into sublime and ridiculous comedy.

headline: ‘Roma’ Review: Alfonso Cuarón’s Masterpiece of Memory
summary_short: Cuarón uses both intimacy and monumentality to express the depths of ordinary life in this autobiographical movie set in Mexico City in the 1970s.

headline: ‘Creed II’ Review: A Poignant Boxing Movie Blends Old and New
summary_short: Michael B. Jordan, Tessa Thompson and Sylvester Stallone reunite in a terrific follow-up to “Creed.”

headline: ‘The World Before Your Feet’ Review: Walk a Mile — or 8,000 — in Another Man’s Shoes
summary_short: Not everyone can spend several years walking every block of New York. But spending 90 minutes doing that in this documentary is swell.

headline: ‘Robin Hood’ Review: A New Version Strains to Be Relevant
summary_short: This is not your father’s, or grandfather’s, “Robin Hood,” and it’s not very good, either.

headline: ‘¡Las Sandinistas!’ Review: Women Remember Revolution in Nicaragua
summary_short: In focusing on the testimonies of women, the documentary aims to memorialize an overlooked feminist “revolution inside the revolution.”

headline: ‘Ralph Breaks the Internet’ Review: Disney Gets Caught in the Web
summary_short: John C. Reilly and Sarah Silverman return to voice the characters in this social satire sequel that is downright scary.

headline: ‘At Eternity’s Gate’ Review: An Exquisite Portrayal of van Gogh at Work
summary_short: A magnificent Willem Dafoe stars in Julian Schnabel’s film, a work that Manohla Dargis calls “an argument for art.”

headline: ‘Green Book’ Review: A Road Trip Through a Land of Racial Clichés
summary_short: A real-life story starring Mahershala Ali and Viggo Mortensen becomes a feel-good fable buoyed by its lead performances.

headline: ‘Of Fathers and Sons’ Review: A Look at Terrorists in Training
summary_short: In this documentary a filmmaker embeds himself with a jihadist family, presenting himself as a sympathizer, but sheds little light on their inner lives.

headline: ‘Miss Dalí’ Review: A Disorienting Biography of Surrealist’s Sister
summary_short: Anna Maria Dalí died four months after her brother, Salvador Dalí. This film is set during that period and is full of reminiscence.

headline: ‘Instant Family’ Review: The Adoption Option, Hollywood Style
summary_short: “Instant Family” is a Sean Anders comedy with good intentions that’s not entirely hellish, but is reliably anodyne.

headline: ‘The Last Race’ Review: Long Island’s Fading Car Craze
summary_short: This documentary explores the region’s long history of auto racing and the lively and eccentric culture it attracted.

headline: ‘Mobile Homes’ Review: Imogen Poots Gives a Riveting Performance
summary_short: In this film about a troubled, unwed mother, director Vladimir de Fontenay struggles to match the expressive power of his lead actress.

headline: ‘Jonathan’ Review: Ansel Elgort as Two Brothers Sharing One Body
summary_short: This often clever sci-fi feature puts new permutations on the concept of burning the candle at both ends.

headline: ‘Under the Wire’ Review: Portrait of a War Reporter
summary_short: The emotional testimony of the war photographer Paul Conroy dominates this heated and harrowing account of Marie Colvin’s last weeks.

headline: ‘Cam’ Review: The Techno-Perils of Online Performance
summary_short: An online sex worker has her identity hijacked in this unusual techno-thriller with an oddly feminist twist.

headline: ‘The Clovehitch Killer’ Review: Unsolved Murders Haunt a Small Town
summary_short: Favoring atmosphere over action, this slow-burning thriller follows the search for a serial killer in a Kentucky town.

headline: ‘Widows’ Review: Viola Davis Commands the Screen in a Somber Heist Film
summary_short: The Oscar-winning director Steve McQueen has delivered a sullen, slow thriller driven by grief and dread, A.O. Scott writes.

headline: ‘The Wild Boys’ Review: Women as Boys, and Violence as Art
summary_short: The film casts five women in the roles of juvenile delinquent boys and takes them on a rough journey to a bizarre island.

headline: ‘Shoah: Four Sisters’ Review: Harrowing Tales of Survival in the Holocaust
summary_short: Claude Lanzmann’s documentary shares the stories of four women through installments that can be watched independently or together.

headline: ‘Infinite Football’ Review: Soccer and Other Existential Questions
summary_short: By its end, the Romanian director Corneliu Porumboiu’s new documentary, nominally about world’s most popular sport, moves onto a plane of mysticism.

headline: ‘Number 37’ Review: A Grungy South African Thriller
summary_short: This slick film is cheerfully derivative yet doggedly entertaining.

headline: ‘Weightless’ Review: A Look at Tough, Working-Class Lives
summary_short: The film, with a screenplay by the playwright Enda Walsh and the director Jaron Albertin, follows a mentally ill man reuniting with his 10-year-old son.

headline: ‘The Ballad of Buster Scruggs’ Review: A Grim Western From the Coen Brothers
summary_short: A.O. Scott says this cowboy anthology is among the silliest Coen brothers films, and also one of the grimmest.

display_title: Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald
headline: ‘Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald’ Review: Apocalypse Too Soon
summary_short: This second installment in J.K. Rowling’s series about a “magizoologist” is so freighted with foreboding that even the would-be whimsy feels leaden.

headline: ‘Overlord’ Review: Old-Fashioned Nazi-Killing, With a Gory Twist
summary_short: The director Julius Avery delivers a fairly predictable action-horror hybrid about American soldiers behind enemy lines.

headline: ‘Outlaw King’ Review: Bloody Medieval Times and Guts
summary_short: Chris Pine stars in a historical slog about Robert the Bruce (1274-1329) that is little more than a churn of mud, entrails and misty nationalism.

headline: ‘The New Romantic’ Review: Experiments With Love and Money
summary_short: A college newspaper columnist writes about her experiences trading gifts for sex in a film that squanders its good will.

headline: ‘Here and Now’ Review: Jazz, Mortality and Sarah Jessica Parker
summary_short: Parker takes on a different kind of role in this morose, contemplative drama.

headline: ‘In a Relationship’ Review: Two Couples at Opposite Stages of Love
summary_short: Sam Boyd’s gentle, loose-limbed romantic comedy wins no prizes for originality.

headline: ‘El Angel’ Review: Tracing a Sociopath’s Destiny
summary_short: The film, which was inspired by a real-life killer, follows Carlitos as he moves from one transgression to the next.

headline: ‘The Long Dumb Road’ Review: Jason Mantzoukas Dispenses Life Lessons
summary_short: This buddy comedy is at its best when it simply chills out with its leads.

headline: ‘Postcards From London’ Review: Small Town Boy Becomes Big City Escort
summary_short: Steve McLean’s film is a pretty movie about pretty boys.

headline: ‘Pimp’ Review: Blaxploitation and Lesbian Love
summary_short: This lurid melodrama follows a female pimp (Keke Palmer) and her girlfriend-prostitute.

headline: ‘Chef Flynn’ Review: A Gastronomic Wonder From Boy to Man
summary_short: This documentary from Cameron Yates looks at Flynn McGarry, a young innovator in dining who tries to live up to his hype.

headline: ‘Dr. Seuss’ The Grinch’ Review: Pointy-Headed and Pointless
summary_short: Aside from colorful computer animation and enhanced cuteness for the lovable sidekick dog, Max, this new “Grinch” brings little of note to the table.

display_title: The Girl in the Spider's Web: A New Dragon Tattoo Story
headline: ‘The Girl in the Spider’s Web’ Review: Lisbeth Salander, Blunted in Tooth and Claw
summary_short: In the latest and emptiest Salander vehicle, the character’s unclassifiable quality has been dulled and contained.

headline: Review: ‘Narcissister Organ Player’ (Partly) Unveils an Artist
summary_short: How does a performance artist whose work relies to some degree on anonymity direct an autobiographical documentary?

headline: Review: A Sex Scandal Upends a Campaign in ‘The Front Runner’
summary_short: Hugh Jackman plays Gary Hart in Jason Reitman’s real-life morality play.

headline: Review: Tyler Perry Turns Tiffany Haddish Loose in ‘Nobody’s Fool’
summary_short: This romantic comedy-drama is a showcase for Haddish, but there’s also some well-placed cameos.

display_title: The Other Side of the Wind
headline: Review: ‘The Other Side of the Wind’ Is Orson Welles’s Haunted Hall of Mirrors
summary_short: Welles’s last project is something of a seductive tease, a film that at times entrances and delights and at times offends and embarrasses.

headline: Review: Marie Colvin Fights ‘A Private War’
summary_short: Rosamund Pike’s powerhouse lead performance anchors Matthew Heineman’s raw, moving portrait of the war correspondent.

headline: Review: ‘Searching for Ingmar Bergman,’ a Misunderstood Artist
summary_short: A new documentary featuring interviews with collaborators and critics makes clear that Bergman, for all his depth, was also an entertainer.

headline: Review: Demystifying a Diva in ‘Maria by Callas’
summary_short: The film proposes a corrective to the notion that Callas was a diva both onstage and off.

headline: Review: ‘Bodied,’ a Shockingly Funny Battle Rap Satire
summary_short: Joseph Kahn’s outrageously smart film uses the battle rap scene to grab P.C. culture by the neck and squeeze.

headline: Review: In ‘The Grief of Others,’ Mourning Becomes Eclectic
summary_short: Patrick Wang’s film, getting a long-overdue theatrical release, looks at a troubled family’s inability to mourn.

display_title: They'll Love Me When I'm Dead
headline: Review: ‘They’ll Love Me When I’m Dead’ Documents Orson Welles’s Last Film
summary_short: Morgan Neville’s movie tells the tumultuous behind-the-scenes story of the making and near-unmaking of “The Other Side of the Wind.”

headline: Review: ‘9 Fingers,’ a Gangster Tale, Is Missing More Than a Digit
summary_short: This new film by F.J. Ossang is a noir pastiche that aspires to a dreamlike state, but doesn’t quite deliver.

headline: Review: In ‘The Price of Free,’ Saving Children Who Are Factory Slaves
summary_short: Kailash Satyarthi, who shared the Nobel Peace Prize in 2014, does inspiring work. But this subject makes for a routine awareness documentary.

headline: Review: ‘Marfa Girl 2,’ Larry Clark’s Sequel to One of His Least-Known Films
summary_short: The film proves that Clark still loves skaters, sex, and sad youth.

headline: Review: A ‘Distant Constellation’ Where Little Is Illuminated
summary_short: Shevaun Mizrahi’s unadorned documentary about Turkish history and identity is too diffuse and withholding to add up to a cogent result.

display_title: Daughters of the Sexual Revolution: The Untold Story of the Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders
headline: Review: In ‘Daughters of the Sexual Revolution,’ Pompoms and Patriotism
summary_short: This gabby, gossipy documentary about the rise of the Dallas Cowboys cheerleaders teeters entertainingly between liberation and exploitation.

display_title: The Nutcracker and the Four Realms
headline: Review: ‘The Nutcracker and the Four Realms’ Is Fine and Forgettable
summary_short: Don’t expect this latest take on the holiday classic to become a yearly tradition.

headline: Review: In ‘Boy Erased,’ a Young Man Struggles With Faith and Sexuality
summary_short: Lucas Hedges, Nicole Kidman and Russell Crowe star in a true story about a discredited (but still practiced) “treatment” for homosexuality.

headline: ‘Bohemian Rhapsody’ Review: Another One Bites the Dust
summary_short: Rami Malek wears prosthetic choppers in a by-the-book biopic of Freddie Mercury and Queen.

headline: Review: In ‘Burning,’ Love Ignites a Divided World
summary_short: The great South Korean director Lee Chang-dong’s latest involves three characters subsumed by desire and rage.

headline: Review: In ‘A Bread Factory,’ Local Artists Face Off Against the World
summary_short: An ambitious, sprawling film about the efforts of a community arts center to survive, “A Bread Factory” is a major new work by a singular American artist.

headline: Review: In ‘A Bread Factory,’ Local Artists Face Off Against the World
summary_short: An ambitious, sprawling film about the efforts of a community arts center to survive, “A Bread Factory” is a major new work by a singular American artist.

headline: Review: ‘Monrovia, Indiana’ Is a Sharp, Lyrical Look at Small-Town America
summary_short: Frederick Wiseman’s visit to Trump country finds that there is more to life than politics, and more to democracy than ideology.

headline: Review: Sniffing Out Guilt in a Strangely Engaging ‘Border’
summary_short: The film, adapted from a short story by the writer of “Let the Right One In,” follows a security guard with an unusual gift.

headline: Review: In ‘Shirkers,’ Stolen Footage and Dashed Dreams
summary_short: Sandi Tan’s captivating documentary about the theft of her first movie by a charismatic con man is both mystery and manhunt.

headline: Review: In ‘Vaya,’ Three Travelers Find Danger in Johannesburg
summary_short: The fate of strangers are darkly intertwined in Akin Omotoso’s electric and empathetic film.

headline: Review: In ‘1985,’ a Young Man Hides a Plague From His Family
summary_short: The film is a moving cinematic sketch of a HIV-infected, closeted gay man living through the height of the AIDS crisis.

headline: Review: In ‘The Dark,’ a Traumatized Teenager Becomes a Zombie
summary_short: The main characters are survivors of childhood abuse, weighty material for a slim film.

headline: Review: ‘Viper Club’ Looks Behind the Scenes of a Press Kidnapping
summary_short: In this film about the kidnapping of an American reporter working in Syria, the mother’s back-channel actions — and reactions — hold the focus.

display_title: Trust Machine: The Story of Blockchain
headline: Review: In Boosting Blockchain, ‘Trust Machine’ Chains Itself In
summary_short: Alex Winter (of “Bill & Ted” fame) explains blockchain technology in this unconvincing documentary.

headline: Review: In ‘Don’t Go,’ Will a Dad’s Dreams Change Reality?
summary_short: A grief-stricken father becomes convinced that by changing the outcome of his dreams, he might bring back the little daughter he and his wife lost.

headline: Review: ‘Hunter Killer’ Explores the Depths of Geopolitics
summary_short: Gerard Butler stars as the captain of an American submarine who must rescue the Russian president.

headline: Review: In ‘London Fields,’ Sex, Apocalypse and Writer’s Block
summary_short: Matthew Cullen’s film is adapted from Martin Amis’s novel about a dying, creatively stalled American writer who has swapped apartments with a celebrated British author.

headline: Review: ‘Foreign Land’ Sees a Better Past Than Future for the Middle East
summary_short: The documentary talks to two friends whose hopes aren’t high for Israelis and Palestinians.

headline: Review: Rowan Atkinson Returns in ‘Johnny English Strikes Again’
summary_short: The character Johnny English has grown slightly less bumbling over the years, and so has the series.

headline: Review: ‘Suspiria’ Is a Gaudy Freakout of Female Violence
summary_short: Luca Guadagnino’s remake of the 1970s Dario Argento freakout is a bloated fantasy of consuming power.

headline: Review: ‘Life and Nothing More’ Places Family in the Center
summary_short: Antonio Méndez Esparza’s keenly observed indie alludes to many hot-button issues but keeps them largely in the background.

headline: Review: In ‘Wildlife,’ Passions Run Rampant
summary_short: The film, directed by Paul Dano and starring Carey Mulligan and Jake Gyllenhaal, is a domestic drama both sad and terrifying.

headline: Review: Bright Young Men Stoop to Scam in ‘Nigerian Prince’
summary_short: This engaging debut feature film by Faraday Okoro asks if there is an honest way for young people to thrive in a country like today’s Nigeria.

headline: Review: ‘On Her Shoulders’ Follows Nobel Peace Prize Winner Nadia Murad
summary_short: The documentary spotlights the hope and weariness of Murad, who was held captive by the Islamic State in Northern Iraq.

headline: Review: ‘The Guilty’ Places a Troubled Police Officer on Hold
summary_short: Gustav Moller’s ingeniously lean thriller builds tension from little more than one police officer, two rooms and a frantic telephone call from a kidnapped woman.

headline: Review: In ‘The Waldheim Waltz,’ a Nation Reckons With Its Nazi Past
summary_short: The Austrian documentarian Ruth Beckermann focuses on Kurt Waldheim, and she is clear on where she stands: She participated in protests against Waldheim.

headline: Review: In ‘Galveston,’ on the Run With Nowhere to Go
summary_short: Ben Foster and Elle Fanning star in this on-the-lam scenario that goes past film noir and lands at film murk.

headline: Review: In ‘What They Had,’ a Family Bickers While a Mother Drifts Away
summary_short: A stellar cast barely rescues Elizabeth Chomko’s predictable first feature about a family matriarch’s slow slide into dementia.

headline: Review: In ‘Caniba,’ a Killer Tries to Make His Case
summary_short: Issei Sagawa, who killed and cannibalized a woman in 1981, is the subject of a new documentary by Véréna Paravel and Lucien Castaing-Taylor.

headline: ‘Halloween’ 1978: The Times Finally Reviews a Horror Classic
summary_short: We didn’t review “Halloween” in 1978 because of a newspaper strike. Forty years later, our critic takes a new look at John Carpenter’s masterpiece.

headline: Review: A Restless Spirit Haunts a Family in ‘A Season in France’
summary_short: Dangerous uncertainty, and a bit of hope, hangs over a family seeking political asylum in Mahamat-Saleh Haroun’s latest feature.

headline: ‘Halloween’ Review: Jamie Lee Curtis, Look Out!
summary_short: David Gordon Green’s sequel to the horror classic brings Michael Myers back for blood.

headline: Review: ‘Mid90s’ Skates Back to a Less Innocent Time
summary_short: This period-specific coming-of-age story was written and directed by Jonah Hill.

headline: Review: Melissa McCarthy Is Criminally Good in ‘Can You Ever Forgive Me?’
summary_short: Marielle Heller directs a true story of literary fraud, set amid the bookstores and gay bars of early ’90s Manhattan.

headline: Review: ‘Charm City’ Vividly Captures the Streets of Baltimore
summary_short: Marilyn Ness’s documentary is dedicated to the memory of the more than 1,000 people said to be killed in Baltimore during the film’s making.

display_title: Horn from the Heart: The Paul Butterfield Story
headline: Review: Paul Butterfield’s Story Is Told in ‘Horn From the Heart’
summary_short: A documentary explores the life of the blues musician who was prominent in the 1960s and ’70s.

headline: Review: ‘The Price of Everything’ Asks $56 Billion Questions About Art
summary_short: This documentary examines the global art market, and pauses to look at some pictures along the way.

headline: Review: ‘Impulso’ Goes Backstage With a Flamenco Innovator
summary_short: This documentary follows Rocío Molina, a cutting-edge dancer, as she prepares for a Paris show.

headline: Review: ‘Watergate’ Shocks Anew With Its True Tale of Political Scandal
summary_short: Charles Ferguson delivers a comprehensive documentary about the not-so-distant past, with its eye very much on the present.

headline: Review: In ‘Barbara,’ a Fictional Biopic of a French Chanteuse
summary_short: It’s a film of scenes rather than of one unified narrative, but each scene is a showcase for the magnificent talents of its star.

headline: Review: A Russian Gymnast Goes ‘Over the Limit’
summary_short: Margarita Mamun endures injury and abuse in Marta Prus’s brilliantly constructed documentary.

headline: Review: The Disturbing Obsession of ‘The Kindergarten Teacher’
summary_short: Maggie Gyllenhaal is riveting as a dissatisfied teacher who’s obsessed with her 5-year-old pupil’s poetic talent.

headline: Review: In ‘Classical Period,’ a Deep Dive — Really Deep — Into Dante
summary_short: This highly original feature is technically in English, but it might as well be in liberal-arts-speak.

display_title: Bad Times at the El Royale
headline: Review: Hard-Boiled Play in ‘Bad Times at the El Royale’
summary_short: The writer-director Drew Goddard has fun with genre and a cast that includes Jeff Bridges, Dakota Johnson, Jon Hamm, Cynthia Erivo and Chris Hemsworth.

headline: Review: In ‘Beautiful Boy,’ a Writer Confronts His Son’s Meth Addiction
summary_short: Two memoirs are brought to the screen in a father-son drama starring Steve Carell and Timothée Chalamet.

headline: Review: In ‘The Oath,’ a Pledge of Allegiance to a President Creates Chasms
summary_short: This satirical comedy, written, directed by and starring Ike Barinholtz, turns dark and ham-handed.

headline: Review: ‘Bikini Moon’ Finds a Documentary Crew Under Its Subject’s Spell
summary_short: Condola Rashad plays the title character, a homeless women who manipulates, and is manipulated by, filmmakers who soon have their own problems.

headline: Review: ‘Goosebumps 2: Haunted Halloween’ Is Toothless Terror
summary_short: This sequel to the movie adaptation of R.L. Stine’s horror series is more goofy than scary.

headline: Review: In ‘The Sentence,’ a Woman Gets Prison, Her Family Also Pays
summary_short: The documentary denounces minimum sentencing laws that put Cindy Shank behind bars.

headline: Review: In ‘All Square,’ Taking Big Bets on Youth Baseball
summary_short: Michael Kelly, Pamela Adlon and Josh Lucas enhance the small-town bookmaking shenanigans of this comedy-drama.

headline: Review: The Drama ‘Sadie’ Finds a Teenager in a Tough Situation
summary_short: The film stars Sophia Mitri Schloss as the title character, a 13-year-old girl who grows angry at the men who are courting her mother.

headline: Review: In ‘After Everything,’ a Young Love Blooms in Crisis
summary_short: This cancer drama focuses less on the high stakes of illness than on how two young people talk to each other in sickness and in health.

headline: Review: ‘First Man’ Takes a Giant Leap for Man, a Smaller Step for Movies
summary_short: Damien Chazelle’s sweeping and intimate yet underwhelming film revisits the first lunar landing, with Ryan Gosling as Neil Armstrong.

headline: Review: Looking Anew at a Norwegian Massacre in ‘22 July’
summary_short: The director Paul Greengrass tries to make sense of a 2011 mass murder by a right-wing extremist who railed against women, Islam and Marxism.

headline: Review: In His Last Years, Oscar Wilde Is Far From ‘The Happy Prince’
summary_short: Written and directed by Rupert Everett, who also stars, the film opens as Wilde is released from prison after serving two years for gross indecency.

headline: Review: In ‘Liyana,’ Swaziland Orphans Turn Hardship Into a Folk Tale
summary_short: The film follows a group of orphans as they take part in a storytelling workshop.

headline: Review: ‘A Crooked Somebody’ Finds a Con Man Caught Up in His Own Plan
summary_short: This thriller follows an opportunistic psychic who furthers his career with the help of a murderer.

headline: Review: Against the Odds, ‘Studio 54’ Sheds Light on the Club
summary_short: The documentary is at its best when focused on Ian Schrager, one of the founders, who hasn’t shared his side of the story in such depth before.

headline: Review: In ‘Wajib,’ a Father and Son Trek Through Nazareth
summary_short: The writer-director Annemarie Jacir adds quiet warmth to the story of a strained but loving relationship in a Christian Palestinian community.

headline: Review: In ‘Wobble Palace,’ a Relationship Hangs by a Stringy Toupee
summary_short: The movie is a sendup of broke-artist types that shimmers with abashed affection.

headline: Review: In ‘Await Further Instructions,’ a Family Home Becomes a Battleground
summary_short: A British family turns on itself when a mysterious substance seals its home in this genuinely upsetting horror-sci-fi hybrid.

headline: Review: ‘Private Life,’ a Piquant Look at a Couple’s Campaign to Conceive
summary_short: Kathryn Hahn and Paul Giamatti star in Tamara Jenkins’s perfect new comedy.

headline: Review: In ‘Venom,’ Tom Hardy as a Weirder-Than-Usual, Not-Quite Superhero
summary_short: The film, which focuses on a popular Marvel character, feels like a body-horror movie played for slapstick.

headline: Review: In ‘Bayou Caviar,’ the Main Course Is a Cold-Blooded Noir
summary_short: A Russian gangster, a blackmail scheme and some hungry alligators in the directorial debut of Cuba Gooding Jr.

display_title: Above and Beyond: NASA's Journey To Tomorrow
headline: Review: ‘Above and Beyond,’ a Heartening Salute to NASA
summary_short: Rory Kennedy’s new documentary is an informative chronicle of American achievements in space.

headline: Review: ‘Shine’ Puts the Focus on Salsa Dancing in Spanish Harlem
summary_short: The movie focuses on two estranged brothers who are at odds, until they head out on the dance floor.

headline: Review: ‘Trouble’ in Vermont, as Two Siblings Fight for Land
summary_short: Anjelica Huston and Bill Pullman play feuding siblings in this dull comedy.

headline: Review: In ‘Viking Destiny,’ a Warrior Princess Reclaims Her Throne
summary_short: This low-budget Nordic caper is about a Viking princess and her stolen throne.

headline: Review: ‘A Star Is Born’ Brings Gorgeous Heartbreak
summary_short: Bradley Cooper, who directed and stars with Lady Gaga, creates thrills with a steadfast belief in old-fashioned, big-feeling cinema.

headline: Review: In ‘The Hate U Give,’ a Police Shooting Forces a Teen to Find Her Voice
summary_short: The timely film, based on Angie Thomas’s young-adult best seller of the same name, takes a wonky leap from page to screen.

headline: Review: ‘The Great Buster’ Brings a Deadpan Genius Back to Life
summary_short: Peter Bogdanovich’s documentary is an affectionate and informative tribute to Buster Keaton, one of the silent era’s great innovators.

headline: Review: ‘Moynihan’ Is a Conventional, Entertaining Political Documentary
summary_short: Joseph Dorman and Toby Perl Freilich’s film traces the career of Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

headline: Review: In ‘Free Solo,’ Braving El Capitan With Only Fingers and Toes
summary_short: This invigorating portrait of the free climber Alex Honnold presents an engaging study of a perfect match between passion and personality.

headline: Review: ‘Bad Reputation’ Argues for Joan Jett’s Importance
summary_short: A new documentary looking at Ms. Jett’s long career — from her all-girl band, the Runaways, in the 1970s to today — casts her as a feminist heroine.

headline: Review: In ‘Monsters and Men,’ Racism Disrupts a Neighborhood
summary_short: Reinaldo Marcus Green’s ambitious debut feature follows the ripples from a police shooting.

headline: Review: ‘All About Nina,’ a Funny Lady (With Issues)
summary_short: Mary Elizabeth Winstead, who plays a stand-up comic in Eva Vives’s ragged feature debut, is so good that she shows you what the movie could have been.

headline: Review: In ‘Summer ’03,’ Coming of Age Is More Bitter Than Sweet
summary_short: The movie’s meanspirited humor is out of place with the perky conventionality of its film style.

headline: Review: In ‘Scaffolding,’ Graduation Is Near. But the Real Lessons Are Ahead.
summary_short: A bullheaded 17-year-old is the focus of this coming-of-age film from Israel.

headline: Review: ‘Smallfoot’ Struggles to Leave an Impression
summary_short: Channing Tatum plays a yeti who prefers the examined life in this animated film.

headline: Review: ‘Matangi/Maya/M.I.A.’ Melds a Rapper’s Music and Activism
summary_short: From a childhood in Sri Lanka to an appearance in the Super Bowl halftime show, a new documentary explores M.I.A.’s eventful life and career.

headline: Review: ‘Black ‘47,’ a Revenge Thriller Set During the Irish Famine
summary_short: A quiet soldier turns into a 19th-century killing machine in Lance Daly’s new film.

headline: Review: In ‘306 Hollywood,’ an Excavation — at Grandma’s House
summary_short: This documentary argues that everyone’s life is worth archiving.

headline: Review: ‘Cruise’ Rides Around the ’80s, With Affection
summary_short: The movie, directed by Robert Siegel, finds Spencer Boldman chasing Emily Ratajkowski through the 1987 streets of Queens.

headline: Review: Robert Redford Aims to Charm in ‘The Old Man & the Gun’
summary_short: Mr. Redford plays a grandfatherly gent with a bank-robbing habit in David Lowery’s new film.

headline: Review: In ‘Hold the Dark,’ Wolves, Gloom and Blood in Alaska
summary_short: In Jeremy Saulnier’s murky follow-up to “Green Room,” Jeffrey Wright goes on an adventure with Riley Keough, Alexander Skarsgard and a pack of wolves.

headline: Review: ‘Night School’ Has Kevin Hart, Tiffany Haddish and a Few Laughs
summary_short: The stars are joined by a motley collection of comic performers in pursuit of a G.E.D.

headline: Review: ‘Colette’ and One Woman’s Lust for Life
summary_short: Keira Knightley stars in the attractive biographical movie “Colette,” which takes a light, enjoyably fizzy approach to its subject.

headline: Review: Blood Is Never Simple in ‘The Sisters Brothers’
summary_short: This period western features an excellent cast in a story about brotherhood, a violent past and the elusive future.

headline: Review: ‘Quincy’ Captures a Lifelong Love Affair With Music
summary_short: A documentary reveals its octogenarian subject as still busy and productive, and not a little haunted by memories of friends now gone.

headline: Review: In ‘Tea With the Dames,’ Four Legends Dish on Acting and Love
summary_short: This documentary with a simple premise — Eileen Atkins, Judi Dench, Joan Plowright and Maggie Smith in conversation — delivers insight and gossip.

headline: Review: In ‘Fahrenheit 11/9,’ Michael Moore Targets Trump, and Us
summary_short: In his new documentary examining the rise of President Trump, the director points fingers at everyone, including himself.

headline: Review: In ‘The Last Suit,’ a Holocaust Survivor Returns Home
summary_short: Instead of moving into a retirement home in Argentina, an elderly man takes a trip to Poland.

headline: Review: ‘Assassination Nation’ Bluntly Calls Out All-American Misogyny
summary_short: Sam Levinson’s bloody social satire offers up a grab bag of trigger warnings and hashtags.

headline: Review: ‘Goyo: The Boy General’ Examines a Philippine Hero
summary_short: The biofilm, based on the experiences of Gregorio del Pilar, sets the stage with sweeping music and proud speeches before the big battle.

headline: Review: ‘Call Her Ganda’ Explores the Murder of a Transgender Woman
summary_short: The documentary looks at the sadness and outrage caused by the 2014 killing of Jennifer Laude by American Marine Joseph Scott Pemberton in the Philippines.

headline: Review: In ‘The Song of Sway Lake,’ Family Resentments Play Out
summary_short: Rory Culkin portrays a young man who goes in search of an old record and discovers more than he expects about his family.

headline: Review: In ‘Love, Gilda,’ a Portrait of a Brief and Brilliant Career
summary_short: Adding to the booming genre of comedian documentaries, this film is an affectionate portrait of one of the first major stars of “Saturday Night Live.”

display_title: The House with a Clock in Its Walls
headline: Review: ‘The House With a Clock in Its Walls’ Is Demented Fun (for Kids)
summary_short: The director Eli Roth, previously known for gory exploitation throwbacks, now makes a nostalgic fun house movie geared toward a younger crowd.

headline: Review: It’s Called ‘Life Itself,’ and Yet Everyone’s Dead
summary_short: Oscar Isaac and Olivia Wilde lead a talented cast on a journey into maudlin ridiculousness.

display_title: Garry Winogrand: All Things are Photographable
headline: Review: ‘Garry Winogrand’ Pictures an Artist and His World
summary_short: The film, subtitled “All Things Are Photographable,” gives the master of street photography the “American Masters” treatment.

headline: Review: Cults, Demons and Nicolas Cage in ‘Mandy’
summary_short: Mr. Cage uses his outsize performing chops to excellent effect in this idiosyncratic revenge fantasy.

headline: Review: In ‘The Land of Steady Habits,’ Suburban Malaise, With a Twist
summary_short: In Nicole Holofcener’s movie, Ben Mendelsohn plays a sad Connecticut dad who blows up his life in the pursuit of something he can’t quite name.

display_title: Hale County This Morning, This Evening
headline: Review: A Multiplicity of Moments in Under 80 Minutes in ‘Hale County’
summary_short: The director RaMell Ross has created a movie that is both a narrative of real lives and an inquiry.

headline: Review: Johnny Rotten Mellows (a Bit) With Age
summary_short: “The Public Image Is Rotten,” a documentary, looks at the post-Sex Pistols career of John Lydon, a.k.a. Johnny Rotten.

headline: Review: In ‘Museo,’ Two Slackers Pull Off a Daring Heist
summary_short: Alonso Ruizpalacios’s new film reconstructs a notorious Mexican art theft, with Gael García Bernal as its disaffected mastermind.

headline: Review: Smother Mother Meets Femme Fatale in ‘A Simple Favor’
summary_short: In his latest, Paul Feig directs Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively in a light-and-dark comedy about two mothers, murderous secrets and complicating lies.

headline: Review: A Prisoner’s Smuggled Plea Sets ‘Letter From Masanjia’ in Motion
summary_short: The documentary tells the tale of a Chinese prisoner whose letter pleading for help was found by an Oregon woman.

headline: Review: ‘Where Hands Touch,’ Set in Nazi Germany, Is a Disturbing Misfire
summary_short: Amma Asante’s film tells the story of a young German woman of color who falls in love with an ardent member of Hitler Youth.

headline: Review: In ‘The Predator,’ Hunting Season Arrives With a Smirk
summary_short: Parody and fan service take precedence in this new entry in the franchise, starring Boyd Holbrook and Olivia Munn. Shane Black directed.

headline: Review: In ‘Don’t Leave Home,’ Irish Folklore Meets Catholic Guilt
summary_short: Michael Tully’s woozy horror movie sends an American artist into a nightmarish Irish legend.

headline: Review: ‘I Think We’re Alone Now’ Finds Peter Dinklage at the End of His World
summary_short: The movie stars Peter Dinklage and Elle Fanning as a pair of survivors in a post-apocalyptic America.

headline: Review: Transfusion and Transference in ‘The Children Act’
summary_short: A need for medical treatment conflicts with a family’s religious beliefs.

headline: Review: In ‘Science Fair,’ High School Students Are World-Class Scholars
summary_short: Teenagers compete to see who will make the largest contribution to humanity.

headline: Review: ‘American Chaos’ Looks at the Election. You Know the End.
summary_short: As James D. Stern began to get a sense of a Trump victory, he set out to interview supporters for this documentary, most of which takes place before the election.

headline: Review: In ‘Bel Canto,’ Music Is the Food of Love and Rebellion
summary_short: Julianne Moore plays an opera singer trapped in a South American mansion in this disappointingly passionless film.

headline: Review: In ‘Lizzie,’ an Oppressed Daughter Driven to Murder
summary_short: Chloë Sevigny plays the famous mom-and-pop slayer as a woman desperate for liberation in 19th-century Massachusetts.

headline: Review: ‘Reversing Roe’ Shows How Abortion Became Political
summary_short: How did abortion become a defining question and a plank in political platforms? This documentary digs into the history of the 1973 decision.

headline: Review: Drugs, Guns and Poses in ‘White Boy Rick’
summary_short: Squint and you see the complex stories that attracted the filmmakers to the life of Richard Wershe Jr., a Detroit dealer arrested at 17 in 1987.

headline: Review: Jean-Pierre Melville’s ‘When You Read This Letter’ Is a Vexing Noir
summary_short: Juliette Gréco, who went on to become a beloved French singer, appears in this 1953 film, which has been restored and rereleased.

headline: Review: ‘Five Fingers for Marseilles’ Takes the Western to South Africa
summary_short: Decades after a killing, a man returns to post-apartheid corruption in his hometown in this picture by Michael Matthews.

headline: Review: Ethan Hawke’s ‘Blaze’ Revisits a Country-Music Legend
summary_short: Mr. Hawke stepped behind the camera to tell the story of Blaze Foley, whose brief life was marked by love, whiskey, friendship, music and whiskey.

headline: Review: ‘Peppermint’ Is Neither Sweet Nor Good
summary_short: Jennifer Garner teams with the director of “Taken” for a hackneyed, dull vigilante thriller that plays into dangerous stereotypes about Latinos.

headline: Review: Tracing the Rise and Fall of the Director Hal Ashby
summary_short: The documentary “Hal” looks at one of the most admired American directors of the 1970s, whose films include “Shampoo” and “Being There.”

headline: Review: ‘Kusama — Infinity’ Gives an Artist Her Due
summary_short: A documentary traces the life of Yayoi Kusama, the painter, sculptor and performance artist known for her mirrored “Infinity” rooms.

headline: Review: In ‘I Am Not a Witch,’ Accusations and Tourism in Zambia
summary_short: When an orphan is accused of witchcraft, she’s taken in by a man who recognizes her potential for business.

headline: Review: ‘Nelly’ Offers a Complex Portrait of a Woman on the Verge
summary_short: Isabelle Fortier, whose pen name was Nelly Arcan, had a literary career — after an earlier one as an escort.

headline: Review: Strong Performances Anchor ‘The Apparition’
summary_short: While the title of Xavier Giannoli’s film sounds like a horror movie, “The Apparition” is more of an investigative drama.

headline: Review: In ‘The Nun,’ a Franchise Resumes Its Scary Habits
summary_short: With this prequel in the “Conjuring” series, the franchise remains a reliable if variably elegant “boo” machine.

headline: Review: In ‘Bisbee ’17,’ Anti-Union Violence Haunts an Arizona Town
summary_short: Robert Greene’s latest documentary uses the re-enactment of a tragedy to examine a legacy of conflict and repression.

headline: Review: ‘This Can’t Happen Here,’ the Film Ingmar Bergman Tried to Bury
summary_short: The movie, restored and playing in New York, was made when the great Swedish director was financially strapped. It’s a melodramatic anti-Communist allegory.

headline: Review: In ‘Prototype,’ Multiple Screens Tell an Apocalyptic Story
summary_short: A handmade film of uncompromising vision, “Prototype” is not your major studio’s 3-D movie.

headline: Review: This ‘Destination Wedding’ Does No One Any Favors
summary_short: Keanu Reeves and Winona Ryder play damaged misanthropes in this grating romantic comedy.

headline: Review: In ‘Let the Corpses Tan,’ Bullets Fly. People Die. But a Story? No.
summary_short: The directors, Hélène Cattet and Bruno Forzani, are more concerned with their own style than with telling a tale.

headline: Review: Teenagers Tackle Environmental Enemies in ‘Inventing Tomorrow’
summary_short: A documentary follows young scientists as they try to create solutions to environmental threats.

headline: Review: ‘Active Measures’ Looks at Links Between Trump and Russia
summary_short: Directed by Jack Bryan, this documentary digs through reams of documents and interviews more than two dozen people, including Hillary Clinton and John McCain.

headline: Review: In ‘Pick of the Litter,’ Good Dogs Compete to Be the Best
summary_short: This unexpectedly suspenseful documentary follows the training of guide dogs for the blind.

headline: Review: In ‘Kin,’ a Futuristic Weapon and Family Troubles
summary_short: This science-fiction film is fantasy wish fulfillment of a laser-blasting sort.

headline: Review: University Spoils a Cinephile in ‘A Paris Education’
summary_short: A student befriends artists and fellow film lovers in this drama from Jean Paul Civeyrac.

headline: Review: In ‘Reprisal,’ With Bruce Willis as Your Neighbor, You Too Can Fight Crime
summary_short: This vigilante thriller is the kind of movie that, once, would have gone straight to video.

headline: Review: In ‘The Little Stranger,’ a Haunted House and a Fading Way of Life
summary_short: Domhnall Gleeson stars as a doctor who gets mixed up with an aristocratic family in Britain in this adaptation of Sarah Waters’s Gothic novel.

headline: Review: In ‘Operation Finale,’ the Agonizing Hunt for a Nazi
summary_short: The film tackles the ethical puzzles facing an Israeli agent played by Oscar Isaac who is part of the team capturing Ben Kingsley’s Adolf Eichmann.

headline: Review: In ‘Support the Girls,’ Sisterhood Is Funny, Essential and Sweet
summary_short: A perfectly cast Regina Hall stars in this stealth charmer about women working in a Texas sports bar, the latest from the director Andrew Bujalski.

headline: Review: ‘Maison du Bonheur,’ a Beguiling Portrait of a Woman in Paris
summary_short: Sofia Bohdanowicz’s documentary captures a way of life through the observations of a delightful woman who has occupied the same apartment for 50 years.

headline: Review: In ‘What Keeps You Alive,’ a Couple, a Cabin and a Crisis
summary_short: A couple’s blissful vacation turns dark in Colin Minihan’s film.

headline: Review: In ‘Hot to Trot,’ a Look at Same-Sex Ballroom Dancing
summary_short: The documentary follows the format that was so successful for the spelling-bee film “Spellbound,” but it doesn’t have the same results.

headline: Review: In ‘Makala,’ the Difficulties of Selling Charcoal in Congo
summary_short: The director, Emmanuel Gras, closely follows a man as he tries to improve his life.

headline: Review: In ‘The Bookshop,’ Seeking Calm, Finding Conflict
summary_short: Emily Mortimer and Bill Nighy form a tender connection in this film adaptation of Penelope Fitzgerald’s 1978 novel.

headline: Review: ‘Blue Iguana’ Takes Two Goofballs, Adds a Caper and Comes Up Empty
summary_short: Sam Rockwell and Ben Schwartz star in this heist film written and directed by Hadi Hajaig.

headline: Review: Economic Anxiety Leads to Violence in ‘Arizona’
summary_short: Rosemarie DeWitt and Danny McBride star in this grisly dark comedy set during the housing meltdown of 2009.

headline: Review: ‘An L.A. Minute’ Isn’t Worth the Time
summary_short: The film, starring Gabriel Byrne, is meant to skewer the mores of Tinseltown.

headline: Review: In ‘Searching,’ a Clever Conceit and John Cho as Leading Man
summary_short: The entirety of the action in Aneesh Chaganty’s psychological thriller unfolds on screens, apps and online.

headline: Review: ‘Crime+Punishment’ Is a Tough Documentary About Police Abuses
summary_short: A filmmaker follows two cases that expose deep-seated problems in the New York Police Department.

headline: Review: Tough Guys Tough It Out in ‘Papillon’ (Again!)
summary_short: Charlie Hunnam and Rami Malek star in a redo of “Papillon,” about the terrible things men do to other men in the name of country and righteousness.

headline: Review: ‘The Happytime Murders’ Has Puppets as Nasty as the Rest of Us
summary_short: Melissa McCarthy and Elizabeth Banks are part of a human cast trading jokes, bullets and bodily fluids with anthropomorphic, felt-covered toys.

headline: Review: In ‘The Rest I Make Up,’ a Playwright’s Life as Memories Ebb
summary_short: The documentary charts the career of María Irene Fornés, and follows her as Alzheimer’s steals her memories.

display_title: John McEnroe: In the Realm of Perfection
headline: Review: ‘John McEnroe’ Captures a Perfectly Imperfect Tennis Star
summary_short: This documentary, subtitled “In the Realm of Perfection,” revisits an era when Mr. McEnroe was on top of the sport.

headline: Review: ‘Minding the Gap’ Is an Astonishing Film About American Life
summary_short: A young director records himself and two skateboarding pals through hard times and painful revelations.

headline: Review: In ‘We the Animals,’ Three Brothers Rush Toward Maturity
summary_short: Jeremiah Zagar’s elemental coming-of-age tale follows mixed-race siblings in upstate New York.

headline: Review: In ‘Mile 22,’ Mark Wahlberg, Patriotism and Paranoia
summary_short: The plot involves a team of covert agents devoted to a level of violence we’re told most people find unpalatable. Peter Berg directs.

headline: Review: ‘Alpha’ Explains How Man’s Best Friend Got That Way
summary_short: A soulful boy bonds with a soulful beast, 20,000 years ago, in this solo feature debut by the director Albert Hughes.

headline: Review: Ghosts and Goofiness Haunt ‘Down a Dark Hall’
summary_short: In Rodrigo Cortés’s teen horror movie, a boarding school has haunts along its hallways.

headline: Review: ‘The Wife’ Looks Behind the Closed Doors of a Literary Marriage
summary_short: Jonathan Pryce, Glenn Close and Christian Slater dig into meaty roles in this adaptation of Meg Wolitzer’s 2003 novel.

headline: Review: In ‘Notes on an Appearance,’ the Hipster Vanishes
summary_short: Watching Ricky D’Ambrose’s experimental mystery film requires learning how to watch it.

headline: Review: ‘Do You Trust This Computer?’ The Quick Answer: Nope
summary_short: The documentary looks at artificial intelligence and warns of a very dangerous world that’s soon to come.

headline: Review: ‘Puppet Master: The Littlest Reich’ Releases Murderous Nazi Dolls
summary_short: This prurient reboot of the “Puppet Master” has unsuspecting conventioneers under attack by dolls.

headline: Review: In ‘Memoir of War,’ a Writer Awaits Her Husband’s Return
summary_short: Mélanie Thierry is an enigmatic Marguerite Duras in this film based on Duras’s semi-autobiographical novel.

headline: Review: ‘A Whale of a Tale’ Fights Back Against ‘The Cove’
summary_short: Megumi Sasaki’s disgruntled documentary attempts to balance Louie Psihoyos’s 2009 film about dolphin capture and slaughter.

headline: Review: Ethan Hawke Is Just Right as a ’90s Indie-Rocker in ‘Juliet, Naked’
summary_short: Rose Byrne and Chris O’Dowd also star in this adaptation of Nick Hornby’s novel.

headline: Review: Looking to the Stars, ‘Cielo’ Can’t Quite Form a Constellation
summary_short: Alison McAlpine’s experimental feature tries to film an essentially unfilmable subject: the night sky above the Atacama Desert in Chile.

headline: Review: ‘Crazy Rich Asians’ Is a Party With a First-Rate Guest List
summary_short: Jon M. Chu’s adaptation of the best-selling novel is a lavish, slyly old-fashioned romantic comedy.

headline: Review: Spike Lee’s ‘BlacKkKlansman’ Journeys Into White America’s Heart of Darkness
summary_short: John David Washington and Adam Driver star in a movie based on a crazy true story from the 1970s, pitched to the crazy realities of right now.

headline: Review: The Vietnam War, as Fought by the French, in ‘The 317th Platoon’
summary_short: This revelatory French-made film, shot in the 1960s and directed by the former war photographer Pierre Schoendoerffer, gets a New York premiere.

headline: Review: In ‘Skate Kitchen,’ a Tight-Knit Group of Girls Takes In a Newcomer
summary_short: A fictional feature that is more of a doc-narrative hybrid, the film directed by Crystal Moselle dives deep into a kind of hangout freedom.

headline: Review: ‘A Prayer Before Dawn’ Drops a British Boxer Into a Thai Prison
summary_short: Jean-Stéphane Sauvaire’s thrillingly impressionistic drama is based on the true story of Billy Moore.

headline: Review: In ‘The Swan,’ Ennui Permeates Rural Iceland
summary_short: A young girl moves from the city to the country and gets her first glimpses of birth, death, sex and betrayal, but boredom is the overriding theme.

headline: Review: In ‘Slender Man,’ Horror Emerges From the Internet
summary_short: A digital urban myth becomes an evil force in Sylvain White’s film.

headline: Review: In ‘Madeline’s Madeline,’ Hazy Boundaries Between Life and Art
summary_short: Josephine Decker delivers an impressionistic portrait of a young woman’s volatile moods and divided loyalties.

headline: Review: In ‘Elizabeth Harvest,’ Forbidden Rooms and Stylized Mystery
summary_short: Sebastian Gutierrez’s thriller is filled with surprises, but each one, paradoxically, makes the movie less and less surprising.

headline: Review: In ‘Dog Days,’ Finding Each Other Through Canine Fandom
summary_short: In Ken Marino’s comedy, a love of dogs brings people together.

headline: Review: ‘BuyBust’ Delivers a Thriller in Manila
summary_short: An elite narcotics squad has a very bad night in Erik Matti’s violent thriller.

headline: Review: ‘The Meg’ Goes on the Rampage, but Barely Makes a Splash
summary_short: Jason Statham battles bite-sized dialogue and finger-puppet characters in this nonsensical monster-shark movie.

headline: Review: ‘The Miseducation of Cameron Post’ Resists the Straight and Narrow
summary_short: Chloë Grace Moretz stars in this adaptation of a popular young-adult novel about faith and sexuality, brought to the screen with empathy and tact.

display_title: King Cohen: The Wild World of Filmmaker Larry Cohen
headline: Review: In ‘King Cohen,’ the Joy of a Low-Budget Auteur
summary_short: This documentary about Larry Cohen, who made films like “It’s Alive” and “The Private Files of J. Edgar Hoover,” is full of lively anecdotes.

headline: Review: ‘Milla’ Is a Stunning Ode to Children Who Become Mothers
summary_short: Set on the craggy beaches of northern France, the film follows a young woman through love, motherhood and poverty.

headline: Review: In ‘Christopher Robin,’ the Hundred Acre Wood Grows Up
summary_short: Marc Forster’s film offers more or less what a Pooh reboot should: a lot of nostalgia, a bit of humor and tactile computer animation.

headline: Review: In ‘Cocote,’ an Ambitious Director Undercuts His Simple Story
summary_short: A pious man is asked to avenge his murdered father in the fictional feature debut of the Dominican filmmaker Nelson Carlo de Los Santos Arias.

headline: ‘The Darkest Minds,’ With Thought Control and Telekinesis
summary_short: In “The Darkest Minds,” the line separating the rote from the metafictional is quite fine.

headline: Review: ‘Night Comes On’ Thoughtfully Contemplates a Teenager’s Revenge
summary_short: This film, about a woman who grew up in foster care, balances penetrating clarity with compassion.

display_title: Scotty and the Secret History of Hollywood
headline: Review: ‘Scotty and the Secret History of Hollywood’ Reveals a Gabby Hollywood Hustler
summary_short: Matt Tyrnauer’s gossipy portrait of Scotty Bowers starts out salty but ends up as something sadder and more complicated.

headline: Review: In ‘Gavagai,’ a Widower on a Quest
summary_short: This high-minded film from Rob Tregenza is about the inability of words in any language to satisfactorily communicate states of being.

headline: Review: Diner Waitresses Rebel in ‘Never Goin’ Back’
summary_short: Propelled by vivacious lead performances, Augustine Frizzell’s tacky yet tender debut feature follows two small-town waitresses on a moneymaking spree.

headline: Review: ‘The Spy Who Dumped Me’ Is a Buddy Comedy With a Body Count
summary_short: Mila Kunis and Kate McKinnon are best friends who help each other through emotional and geopolitical chaos in this silly, bloody movie.

headline: Review: ‘Nico, 1988’ Dramatizes the Singer’s Tormented Final Years
summary_short: A biopic about the Velvet Underground vocalist thrums with nervous energy as it depicts her struggles with heroin and a jagged relationship with her suicidal son.

headline: Review: In ‘Rendezvous in July,’ Young Parisians Are on the Move
summary_short: A 1949 Jacques Becker movie is abundant in wit, charm and soul; it has its American debut at Film Forum.

headline: Review: In ‘No Date, No Signature,’ a Doctor Seethes With Guilt Over a Boy’s Death
summary_short: A sturdy morality play, the film explores the lives of two men, each with a limited sense of what the other knows.

headline: Review: In ‘Prairie Trilogy,’ All-American Stories of Socialism
summary_short: Three films made between 1977 and 1980 recount the efforts of a labor union in North Dakota shortly before World War I.

headline: Review: ‘Good Manners’ Is a Twisty Werewolf Tale From Brazil
summary_short: This genre-twisting film from Juliana Rojas and Marco Dutra successfully joins art house to slaughterhouse.

headline: Review: ‘Killer Bees’ Tracks Working-Class Athletes in the Hamptons
summary_short: The documentary, directed by Benjamin and Orson Cummings, follows the Killer Bees, a predominantly African-American high school basketball team.

headline: Review: ‘Scarred Hearts’ Entraps a Young Man and His Illness
summary_short: Grueling but fascinating, Radu Jude’s film freely adapts the writings of the Romanian author M. Blecher.

headline: Review: In ‘The Captain,’ a Sadistic Nazi Is an Impostor
summary_short: The film is based on the true story of a private who portrayed a Nazi captain and embarked on a brutal odyssey at the end of World War II.

headline: Review: In ‘The Bleeding Edge,’ Victims of Medical Devices
summary_short: This documentary examines how poor regulation and corporate influence contribute to patients’ painful injuries.

display_title: Teen Titans Go! To the Movies
headline: Review: In ‘Teen Titans Go! To the Movies,’ It Takes a Superhero to Spoof One
summary_short: The animated comedy finds a team of young crusaders fighting a villain and making fun of superhero franchises.

headline: Review: ‘Damascus Cover’ Has Cloaks and Daggers, but That’s All
summary_short: Everything you need for a spy movie, but not everything you want.

headline: Review: ‘Our House’ Comes Equipped With More Than Wi-Fi
summary_short: Violating the laws of physics is rarely a good idea. For evidence, see “Our House.”

headline: Review: Piecing Together a Life in ‘Puzzle’
summary_short: Kelly Macdonald and Irrfan Khan play competitive puzzle partners in this low-key, high-stakes domestic drama, directed by Marc Turtletaub.

headline: Review: ‘Hot Summer Nights’ Is Trite, Sexist Opportunism
summary_short: Timothée Chalamet plays a city kid trying to adjust to life in a small beach town in this film from the newcomer Elijah Bynum.

headline: ‘Mission: Impossible — Fallout’ and the Bliss of the Hyper-Human Tom Cruise
summary_short: Mr. Cruise works hard in a movie that embraces the oldies (blonde with knife in garter) while pushing to greater spectacle-cinema extremes.

headline: Review: ‘93Queen’ Follows Female Jewish EMS Workers in Brooklyn
summary_short: The feature debut of Paula Eiselt tells of the creation of Ezras Nashim, an all-female EMS corps for the Borough Park area, in Brooklyn.

headline: Review: ‘Pin Cushion’ Is an Original Tale of Bullying and Mental Illness
summary_short: This debut feature from the British director Deborah Haywood follows a teenager and her mother as they struggle to fit in to a new town.

headline: Review: ‘Unfriended: Dark Web’ Reveals New Terrors of the Internet
summary_short: A young man finds hidden files, and plenty of danger, on a laptop in this thriller that plays out on a computer screen.

headline: Review: ‘McQueen’ Reveals a Dazzling and Divisive Talent
summary_short: A documentary from Ian Bonhôte explores the recurring motif of triumph over abuse in the fashion designer’s world.

headline: Review: Denzel Washington Plays Judge, Jury and Executioner in ‘The Equalizer 2’
summary_short: Antoine Fuqua directs this violent, indefensibly entertaining sequel about an avenger who dispenses pulverizing justice one broken bone at a time.

headline: Review: ‘Generation Wealth’ Examines Toxic Materialism
summary_short: Lauren Greenfield’s emotionally complicated documentary looks deeper into our obsession with money and status.

headline: Review: ‘Far From the Tree’ Zooms In on Parent-Child Divides
summary_short: This documentary, an adaptation of the best-selling book by Andrew Solomon, deals with living with Down syndrome or autism, and other family matters.

headline: Review: In ‘The Third Murder,’ Guilty as Charged Isn’t the Whole Story
summary_short: A defense lawyer finds that the more he searches for the truth the more it slips away in the latest from the Japanese filmmaker Hirokazu Kore-eda.

display_title: Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again
headline: Review: ‘Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again’ Takes a Detour and Loses Its Kick
summary_short: Almost every member of the original cast of “Mamma Mia!” is back for this sequel, except for one major player. And, boy, is she missed.

headline: Review: ‘Blindspotting’ Walks a Tense Line in a Gentrifying Oakland
summary_short: Written by and starring Daveed Diggs and Rafael Casal, the film struggles to balance its ambition as an entertainment with its social concerns.

display_title: The Rise and Fall of a Small Film Company
headline: Review: A Godard Film About Making Movies Arrives in New York
summary_short: “The Rise and Fall of a Small Film Company,” a made-for-TV movie by Jean-Luc Godard, is having its New York premiere in a new restoration.

headline: Review: In ‘The Other Side of Everything,’ a Belgrade Apartment Symbolizes Upheaval
summary_short: After the revolution, the real work begins. Toppling a leader can be a hollow victory when there is no clear plan to fill the void.

headline: Review: ‘Milford Graves Full Mantis’ Delivers a Lot of Heart
summary_short: This documentary about the jazz drummer speaks to the pulse of life.

headline: Review: In ‘What Will People Say,’ Tyranny Begins at Home
summary_short: The director Iram Haq translated a personal story to the screen for this domestic kidnapping thriller.

headline: Review: Tracking ‘Dark Money’ in Montana Elections
summary_short: In her documentary, Kimberly Reed explores how Montanans fought a political invasion backed by wealthy anonymous donors.

headline: Review: Keanu Reeves, Selling Ice in a Dull ‘Siberia’
summary_short: Mr. Reeves plays a diamond merchant who falls for a cafe owner in this leaden thriller.

headline: Review: Raising the Stakes With ‘Hotel Transylvania 3: Summer Vacation’
summary_short: Adam Sandler lends his voice as Dracula again in the third installment of this animated franchise.

headline: Review: In ‘Shock and Awe,’ Journalists Expose Gaps in Case for Iraq War
summary_short: This intermittently rousing procedural chronicles the news company Knight Ridder’s skeptical stance toward the Bush administration’s case for war.

headline: Review: ‘Path of Blood’ Presents Terrorists’ Videos
summary_short: This documentary commands attention as an object lesson in the banality of evil.

headline: Review: Sinfulness and Scares Behind ‘The Devil’s Doorway’
summary_short: Aislinn Clarke’s outraged horror movie sends two priests to investigate a home for fallen women.

headline: Review: In ‘The Night Eats the World,’ Zombie Apocalypse Now, Again
summary_short: Dominque Rocher’s feature debut finds new ways to drain all the fun out of flesh-eating monsters.

headline: Review: All the Feels, Hurts and Laughs of ‘Eighth Grade’
summary_short: In his feature directing debut, the comic Bo Burnham delivers a moving portrait of the YouTube artist as a comically, painfully true young girl.

headline: Review: In ‘Skyscraper,’ Dwayne Johnson Scales a Tower of Clichés
summary_short: The performer formerly known as the Rock proves again that he can surmount even a pile of recycled genre standards.

display_title: Don't Worry, He Won't Get Far on Foot
headline: Review: Joaquin Phoenix Treks the Long Road to Sobriety in ‘Don’t Worry’
summary_short: Mr. Phoenix plays the disabled alcoholic cartoonist John Callahan in Gus Van Sant’s cleverly volatile biopic.

headline: Review: ‘Gauguin: Voyage to Tahiti’ Doesn’t Make Much of a (Post-) Impression
summary_short: The film, starring Vincent Cassel, depicts (and sanitizes) the painter’s first experiences living in French Polynesia.

headline: Review: In ‘The Citizen,’ an Immigrant Picks a Bad Time to Fall in Love
summary_short: This Hungarian film is a careful, compassionate and beautifully acted character drama with a social conscience.

headline: Review: An Icelandic Suburb Hides Deep Dysfunction ‘Under the Tree’
summary_short: In this pitch-black Icelandic farce, a suburban feud over a lovely old tree threatens to destroy two families.

headline: Review: ‘Ryuichi Sakamoto: Coda’ Shows a Composer Attuned to Nature
summary_short: Stephen Nomura Schible’s film is an uncommonly engaging artist portrait.

headline: Review: ‘Whitney,’ a Pop Music Tragedy, Is Sad, Strange and Dismaying
summary_short: A new documentary argues for the unhappy life of Whitney Houston, who died in 2012.

headline: Review: ‘Moss’ Meanders Through a Southern Coming-of-Age
summary_short: The sense of place is as pervasive as a character in “Moss,” a film by Daniel Peddle.

headline: Review: Six Strongmen Cultivate ‘A Skin So Soft’
summary_short: Denis Côté’s latest documentary is an artfully surreal study of dedicated musclemen.

headline: Review: In ‘Constructing Albert,’ a Chef’s Ambition, Meticulously Plated
summary_short: Filmmakers follow the Spanish chef Albert Adrià as he works to open the restaurant Enigma in Barcelona.

headline: Review: Jackie Chan Battles a Goofy Plot in ‘Bleeding Steel’
summary_short: It’s a ridiculous movie, but Jackie Chan is still the most talented and witty athlete in cinema.

headline: Review: ‘Ant-Man and the Wasp’ Save the World! With Jokes!
summary_short: Paul Rudd, Evangeline Lilly and a host of other familiar faces join this latest Marvel adventure.

headline: Review: On Staten Island, ‘The First Purge’ Rages
summary_short: This prequel to the popular franchise outlines the events preceding the annual slash-a-thon and wonders: What if you held a massacre and hardly anyone came?

display_title: Fireworks, Should We See It from the Side or The Bottom?
headline: Review: In ‘Fireworks,’ Second Chances, but No Magic
summary_short: From a producer of “Your Name,” “Fireworks” doesn’t realize its potential, our critic writes.

headline: Review: ‘Sorry to Bother You,’ but Can I Interest You in a Wild Dystopian Satire?
summary_short: In his debut feature, starring Lakeith Stanfield, Boots Riley takes on race, class, technology and telemarketing.

headline: Review: ‘Leave No Trace’ Is a Very American Story About Survival
summary_short: Ben Foster and Thomasin Harcourt McKenzie play father and daughter in the latest movie from Debra Granik, the director of “Winter’s Bone.”

headline: Review: A Child Adds a Layer to Gay Couple’s ‘Ideal Home’
summary_short: Chemistry between the stars, Steve Coogan and Paul Rudd, aids the poignant and pithy script, which is based on the director’s own experiences.

headline: Review: A ‘Dark River’ of Abuse Separates a Brother and Sister from Their Inheritance
summary_short: Ruth Wilson gives a tough, traumatized performance in Clio Barnard’s Yorkshire-set psychodrama.

headline: Review: A German ‘Cakemaker’ and an Israeli Widow Share Loss and Cookies
summary_short: Drool-worthy confectionery expresses unspoken emotions in first feature from the writer and director Ofir Raul Graizer.

headline: Review: In ‘Hover,’ the Drone Tech Isn’t All There
summary_short: Matt Osterman’s allegorical thriller, written by its star, Cleopatra Coleman, flirts with topicality on several fronts.

headline: Review: In ‘This Is Congo,’ Four Lives Shaken by Conflict
summary_short: “This Is Congo” aims to deliver a portrait of the Democratic Republic of Congo from the ground up.

headline: Review: In ‘Love, Cecil,’ an Aesthete Ahead of His Time
summary_short: Lisa Immordino Vreeland’s new documentary is about Cecil Beaton, the British dandy, photographer and theatrical designer.

headline: Review: A ‘Woman Walks Ahead,’ and Sitting Bull Stands Up
summary_short: Jessica Chastain and Michael Greyeyes are marvelous in this gorgeous, romanticized tale of the 19th-century artist who painted Sitting Bull’s portrait.

headline: Review: In ‘Uncle Drew,’ N.B.A. Stars Keep Dunking With Age
summary_short: This basketball comedy is amusing and kindhearted, but strangely bland.

headline: Review: For These ‘Recovery Boys,’ Sobriety Is a Steep Climb
summary_short: Four young opioid addicts in West Virginia tackle recovery and sober living in this raw and moving documentary.

headline: Review: In ‘Custody,’ a Father Terrorizes His Family
summary_short: A powerful French film from Xavier Legrand lays bare the logic of domestic abuse.

headline: Review: The Surreal, Heartbreaking Case of ‘Three Identical Strangers’
summary_short: Engrossing and sometimes enraging, this documentary tells of triplets who, after being separately adopted at birth, were later reunited.

headline: Review: ‘Rock Rubber 45s’ Looks in the Mirror to Tell a Life Story
summary_short: The cultural entrepreneur Bobbito Garcia directs this documentary about a familiar subject: himself.

headline: Review: In ‘Winter Brothers,’ a Frosty Sibling Rivalry
summary_short: This film, about brothers who work at a factory, is a mix of the bleak and the absurdist.

headline: Review: ‘Sicario: Day of the Soldado’ Blends War Movie and Western
summary_short: This sequel to “Sicario,” starring Benicio Del Toro and Josh Brolin, is also a geopolitical action thriller and a samurai picture.

headline: Review: ‘The King’ Chases the American Dream and Elvis
summary_short: This seductive documentary tracks the rise and fall of Elvis Presley, a tragic arc that the director Eugene Jarecki likens to that of the United States.

headline: Review: This ‘Damsel’ Needs No Saving
summary_short: Robert Pattinson discovers that Mia Wasikowska is not in distress in this entertainingly original western from the Zellner brothers.

headline: Review: In ‘Araby,’ the Story of a Wandering Laborer
summary_short: This Brazilian drama from João Dumans and Affonso Uchôa is about the nagging sadness of life.

display_title: Marlina the Murderer in Four Acts
headline: Review: Vengeance Is Hers in ‘Marlina the Murderer in Four Acts’
summary_short: In this Indonesian movie, a woman hits the road with her assailant’s severed head.

headline: Review: Mackenzie Davis Gets ‘Across Town,’ With Diversions
summary_short: Ms. Davis and Carrie Coon have a great moment, but it’s not enough to carry the burden of an entire movie.

headline: Review: ‘Spiral’ Chronicles the Impact of Prejudice on Everyday Lives
summary_short: Laurie Fairrie’s documentary profiles individuals and families in France and Israel to capture a cycle of fear and xenophobia.

headline: Review: A Father and Daughter Renegotiate ‘Boundaries’
summary_short: A fine cast, led by Vera Farmiga and Christopher Plummer, is the sole pleasure in this superficial road-trip movie.

headline: Review: ‘The Catcher Was a Spy’ Shares a Peculiar History Lesson
summary_short: Paul Rudd portrays Moe Berg, a professional baseball player who worked as a spy for the United States during World War II.

headline: Review: ‘Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom’ Brings the Gang Back. Sigh.
summary_short: Extinction is not an option, but exhaustion is a distinct possibility.

headline: Review: John Travolta Has the Dapper Look, but ‘Gotti’ Is a Mess
summary_short: Poorly directed by Kevin Connolly, the film about the mobster fails to cohere as a story and its view on the title character is never clear.

headline: Review: In ‘The Yellow Birds,’ Two Soldiers Deploy, but Only One Comes Home
summary_short: Terrific performances and vivid photography distinguish this melancholy war drama about the disappearance of a young Army recruit.

headline: Review: ‘Tag,’ You’re It. Playing the Long Game Into Middle Age.
summary_short: Hannibal Buress, Jon Hamm, Jake Johnson and Ed Helms star as friends who refuse to put away childish things.

headline: Review: ‘Eating Animals’ Skewers Factory Farming
summary_short: Christopher Quinn’s documentary makes a persuasive, far-ranging case against factory farming.

headline: Review: ‘The Year of Spectacular Men’ Is a Family Affair, Clichés Included
summary_short: Lea Thompson directed her daughters in a mostly sweet comedy about sisters in their 20s.

headline: Review: ‘Straight Into a Storm,’ a Look at the Cult Band Deer Tick
summary_short: In this documentary, the singer-songwriter John McCauley and his bandmates enact the bad-boy antics of rock over a decade in Deer Tick.

headline: Review: ‘Incredibles 2’ Is a Fast Blast (With Red Flags)
summary_short: In their new adventure, a sequel to the 2004 hit, Elastigirl, Mr. Incredible and their super-kids again fight the good fight at home and in the world.

headline: Review: In ‘Gabriel and the Mountain,’ Recalling a Tragic Adventure
