summary_short: Fellipe Gamarano Barbosa’s film blends documentary and fiction techniques to reconstruct a young Brazilian’s travels in East Africa.

display_title: Five Seasons: The Gardens of Piet Oudolf
headline: Review: ‘Five Seasons’ Explores the Garden Designer Behind the High Line
summary_short: This film, subtitled “The Gardens of Piet Oudolf,” is a conventional documentary. It follows Mr. Oudolf as he holds forth on his philosophy.

headline: Review: ‘Superfly’ Adds Bling to an Old Tale
summary_short: This remake of a 1972 film focuses on the drug trade and the pursuit of wealth in Atlanta.

headline: Review: In ‘Hereditary,’ the Horror Is Slow-Cooked and Homemade
summary_short: Toni Collette stars as a mother facing diabolical family issues in Ari Aster’s debut feature.

headline: Review: In ‘En el Séptimo Día,’ He Wants to Work and Play. What Will He Do?
summary_short: This indie drama from Jim McKay feels utterly natural as it ratchets with the mechanics of drama and suspense.

headline: Review: ‘Westwood: Punk, Icon, Activist,’ a Portrait in Brief
summary_short: A fast, funny documentary on the life, looks and times of the British fashion designer and unreconstructed punk Vivienne Westwood, who cannot be bothered.

headline: Review: In ‘The Valley,’ Life and Death Meet Technology
summary_short: A Silicon Valley entrepreneur’s obsessive search to learn why his daughter killed herself.

headline: Review: ‘The Quest of Alain Ducasse’ Follows the Tastes of a Chef
summary_short: This near-hagiographic documentary goes around the world with Mr. Ducasse, who in 1987 became one of the youngest chefs with three Michelin stars.

headline: Review: Jamming Together, a Father and Daughter’s ‘Hearts Beat Loud’
summary_short: Nick Offerman and Kiersey Clemons play a father-daughter musical duo in this pleasantly vanilla film.

headline: Review: ‘Bernard and Huey’ Has Wit and Personality. Stale Jokes, Too.
summary_short: “Bernard and Huey,” starring David Koechner and Jim Rash, is a portrait of two old friends and their hapless negotiations with their lives.

headline: Review: ‘Half the Picture’ Aims a Spotlight on Hollywood’s Sexism
summary_short: Ava DuVernay and Lena Dunham join a chorus of female filmmakers speaking out in Amy Adrion’s documentary.

headline: Review: ‘The Workers Cup’ Is a Sports Movie and an Economics Lesson
summary_short: The documentary watches a team of migrant workers in Qatar who play soccer in and around the stadiums they are building for the World Cup.

headline: Review: In ‘Nancy,’ a Troubled Woman Seeks Connection
summary_short: Christina Choe’s debut feature is an uncompromisingly miserable portrait of delusion and damage.

headline: Review: Take the Next Trolley to ‘Won’t You Be My Neighbor?’
summary_short: Morgan Neville’s new documentary is an affectionate, intelligent portrait of a public television hero, Mister Rogers.

headline: Review: Jodie Foster Presides at ‘Hotel Artemis’
summary_short: This crime thriller set in the near future features a strong turn by Ms. Foster.

headline: Review: ‘Ocean’s 8’ Women Walk Away With a Male Franchise. Sort Of.
summary_short: Sandra Bullock, Cate Blanchett, Rihanna and friends are fun to watch. Too bad the movie doesn’t play with gender as lightly (and seriously) as with genre.

headline: Review: In ‘Action Point,’ the ‘Jackass’ Crew Plays It Safe
summary_short: Johnny Knoxville and Chris Pontius star in a laugh-deprived comedy about a dangerous amusement park.

headline: Review: In ‘Breath,’ Tasty Waves and Gnomic Truths
summary_short: In his feature directing debut, the actor Simon Baker plays a surfing guru who tutors two teens in the Way of the Wave.

headline: Review: Shailene Woodley Braves the Elements in ‘Adrift’
summary_short: A true story of survival at sea, directed by Baltasar Kormakur.

headline: Review: In ‘A Kid Like Jake,’ Parents, Gender and a 4-Year-Old
summary_short: When Brooklyn parents, played by Claire Danes and Jim Parsons, are told that their son enjoys “gender expansive play,” things get interesting.

headline: Review: ‘Rodin,’ a Biopic Heavy as Stone
summary_short: The film about the sculptor offers two hours of actors struggling to appear lifelike.

headline: Review: In ‘Social Animals,’ Stalled Lives and Sexual Frustrations
summary_short: Noël Wells and Josh Radnor play Austin slackers in this mildly entertaining sex comedy.

headline: Review: In ‘Nossa Chape,’ Soccer Club Rebuilds After Devastating Loss
summary_short: A new documentary follows the Chapecoense, a Brazilian soccer team, after 19 of its players were killed in a plane crash.

headline: Review: ‘The Doctor From India’ Pushes Nontraditional Medicine
summary_short: The documentary focuses on Vasant Lad and his claims that ayurveda can cure various ailments.

headline: Review: In ‘Upgrade,’ Better Killing Through Technology
summary_short: The futuristic world of “Upgrade” creates a perfect killing machine out of Logan Marshall-Green.

headline: Review: In ‘American Animals,’ These Guys Didn’t Visit the Library to Study
summary_short: A movie about a real-life rare-book heist.

headline: Review: ‘Future World,’ With James Franco, Is Present-Tense Wretchedness
summary_short: For this postapocalyptic trifle, the actor also directs, along with Bruce Thierry Cheung.

headline: Review: In ‘Who We Are Now,’ Chaotic Lives Intersect
summary_short: Julianne Nicholson is an ex-con and Emma Roberts is an attorney in this film by Matthew Newton.

headline: Review: A Young Orphan Finds a New Home in ‘Summer 1993’
summary_short: This autobiographical debut from the writer and director Carla Simón is light on drama yet dense with unspoken feeling.

headline: Review: ‘Les Parents Terribles,’ From Jean Cocteau, in a New Restoration
summary_short: This 1948 family melodrama gets its U.S. theatrical premiere.

display_title: How to Talk to Girls at Parties
headline: Review: An Alien Teaches a Teenage Punk ‘How to Talk to Girls at Parties’
summary_short: John Cameron Mitchell’s loony romantic comedy encourages young love to bloom in the soil of an alien visitation.

headline: Review: ‘In Darkness’ Finds a Blind Pianist Wrapped Up in a Murder
summary_short: Natalie Dormer, who stars in the film, also wrote it with the director, Anthony Byrne. Set in London, the mystery also stars Emily Ratajkowski.

headline: Review: Deep in the Woods, Something ‘Feral’ Stirs
summary_short: This methodical and efficient cabin-in-the-woods horror movie subjects college graduates to a zombie infection.

headline: Review: ‘The Misandrists’ Makes a Mockery of Matriarchies and Patriarchies Alike
summary_short: Bruce LaBruce’s film turns lesbian separatism into satire.

headline: Review: ‘The Gospel According to André’ Barely Scratches the Surface
summary_short: A documentary about the fashion world Zelig André Leon Talley doesn’t live up to his energy.

headline: Review: ‘Mary Shelley’ Twists Pain and Passion Into a Monster
summary_short: Elle Fanning portrays a writer of, and ahead of, her time as the film traces the origin story of “Frankenstein.”

headline: Review: ‘First Reformed’ Is an Epiphany. Ethan Hawke Is, Too.
summary_short: Paul Schrader’s film about a tormented pastor is a study of spiritual and political despair that is a quiet cinematic revelation.

headline: Review: In ‘Sollers Point,’ a Hard Road to the Straight and Narrow
summary_short: In this film from Matthew Porterfield, a just-out-of-prison young man contends with bad luck and his own unwise impulses.

headline: Review: ‘Show Dogs’ Is a Shaggy Good Time
summary_short: In Raja Gosnell’s canine comedy, a Rottweiler teams up with a human crime-fighting partner to thwart an international animal smuggling ring.

headline: Review: In ‘Saving Brinton,’ an Inveterate Accumulator Finds Treasure
summary_short: This documentary explores the world of Michael Zahs, a collector who locates a home — other than his — for his enormous trove of memorabilia.

headline: Review: ‘Dark Crimes’ Finds Jim Carrey as a Brooding Cop
summary_short: The movie, loosely based on a real murder case, is set in Poland as the police seek a killer whose crimes seemed to be detailed in a novel.

headline: Review: ‘That Summer’ Sheds Light on the Beales Before ‘Grey Gardens’
summary_short: A new documentary, directed by Goran Hugo Olsson, sheds further light on Big Edie and Little Edie, with footage from 1972.

headline: Review: ‘The Most Unknown’ Tackles Science’s Big Questions
summary_short: The documentary interviews nine scientists in fields including astronomy and neuroscience, and asks them to reflect on their work.

display_title: Pope Francis: A Man of His Word
headline: Review: In ‘Pope Francis: A Man of His Word,’ a Religious Leader Speaks at Length
summary_short: The head of the Roman Catholic Church answers questions in this feature from Wim Wenders.

headline: Review: In ‘On Chesil Beach,’ a Honeymoon Gone Wrong
summary_short: The film is a careful, effective adaptation of Ian McEwan’s novel of intimacy and heartbreak, starring Saoirse Ronan and Billy Howle.

headline: Review: In ‘Book Club,’ Women, Wine and the Pursuit of More
summary_short: Four screen goddesses — Jane Fonda, Diane Keaton, Mary Steenburgen and Candice Bergen — play characters searching for their inner goddesses.

headline: Review: ‘Solo: A Star Wars Story’ Answers Questions You May Not Have Asked
summary_short: Where did Han Solo get his last name? How did he and Chewbacca meet? What was the hand of Sabacc that won him the Millennium Falcon?

headline: Review: ‘Deadpool 2’ Has More Swearing, Slicing and Dicing From Ryan Reynolds
summary_short: This sequel to the 2016 R-rated superhero hit pokes fun at the genre while staying true to its conventions.

headline: Review: A Married Woman Longs for ‘The Escape’
summary_short: In Dominic Savage’s film, a young wife and mother (a fabulous Gemma Arterton) becomes aware that the life she has may not be the one she wants.

headline: Review: A Troubled Beauty and a Mysterious ‘Beast’
summary_short: The Island of Jersey is turned into a trap in this thriller from the director Michael Pearce.

headline: Review: ‘Breaking In’ Finds Gabrielle Union as a Mother on a Mission
summary_short: The thriller is set at a remote Wisconsin location, where a group of thugs holds two kids hostage in a high-security house.

headline: Review: In ‘Life of the Party,’ Melissa McCarthy Goes to College
summary_short: TFW your mom is also your sorority sister. Lol. AWKWARD!

headline: Review: Jonas Mekas Is Left in the Dark in ‘I Had Nowhere to Go’
summary_short: Mr. Mekas, the tireless avant-garde filmmaker and artist, is the subject of an unconventional documentary by Douglas Gordon.

headline: Review: A Mermaid Saves the Day in ‘Lu Over the Wall’
summary_short: In this new anime adventure from the director Masaaki Yuasa, a musical mermaid’s powers transform a melancholy student and his town.

headline: Review: ‘Filmworker’ Reveals Stanley Kubrick’s Perfectionism
summary_short: Leon Vitali, Kubrick’s longtime assistant, details what it took to satisfy his demanding but beloved boss in a new documentary.

headline: Review: ‘Mountain’ Features Frightening Sights and Breathtaking Images
summary_short: The documentary, a meditation on mountains and those who risk their lives on them, is set to music performed by the Australian Chamber Orchestra.

headline: Review: Revenge Goes Sour in ‘Terminal’
summary_short: In this hackneyed noir pastiche, Margot Robbie leads a handful of hard-boiled characters through a Tarantino-esque dystopia.

headline: Review: ‘Anything’ Finds a Small-Town Man Baffled by the Big City
summary_short: The film, starring John Carroll Lynch, finds a strait-laced widower bonding with a transgender woman, played by Matt Bomer.

headline: Review: ‘The Day After’ and the Awkwardness of Lunch With the Boss
summary_short: A tiny Seoul publishing house is the scene of questionable workplace conduct in Hong Sang-soo’s latest comedy of boozy bad manners.

display_title: Boom for Real: The Late Teenage Years of Jean-Michel Basquiat
headline: Review: ‘Boom for Real’ Is a Beguiling Look at a Teenage Basquiat
summary_short: The director Sara Driver pays the artist proper and enthralling tribute in this documentary, which is as distinctive as her fictional films.

headline: Review: ‘Always at the Carlyle’ Hints at Scandal, Chooses Discretion
summary_short: Matthew Miele’s documentary about the Carlyle Hotel, on the Upper East Side, is more interested in burnishing a reputation than in exploring it.

headline: Review: In ‘Revenge,’ the Trophy Turns Hunter
summary_short: Coralie Fargeat’s debut feature is a skillful and gory fusion of feminism and exploitation.

headline: Review: In ‘The Seagull,’ a Great Play, a Great Cast and Yet ...
summary_short: Annette Bening, Saoirse Ronan and Elisabeth Moss are highlights of Michael Mayer’s adaptation of the durable Chekhov play.

headline: Review: ‘Angels Wear White’ Is a Searing Tale of Moral Rot in China
summary_short: The story of young women struggling in a beach town is plotted like a suspense thriller, with many characters up to their necks in corruption.

headline: Review: Lonely in Los Angeles, Until ‘Ray Meets Helen’
summary_short: Alan Rudolph’s new film has a wistful, whimsical sophistication that has all but disappeared from movies.

headline: Review: ‘Overboard’ Remake Is So Sweet It Makes the Original Look Edgy
summary_short: The American comedic treasure Anna Faris is paired with the Mexican star Eugenio Derbez in this likable, if not hilarious, retelling of the 1987 movie.

headline: Review: In the Comedy ‘Tully,’ Mom’s Struggle Is Real
summary_short: Charlize Theron plays an overwhelmed mother who needs all the help she can get — and gets a magical, mysterious night nurse played by Mackenzie Davis.

headline: Review: In ‘Everything Else,’ Extreme Isolation in Mexico City
summary_short: The story’s tragedy gradually accumulates as the film follows the daily routine of a 63-year-old government clerk.

headline: Review: To Catch a Thief, Drive a Fast Car in ‘Racer and the Jailbird’
summary_short: The two leads in this thriller are sensational, but the movie is stuffed with confusing plot complications.

headline: Review: In ‘Strangers on the Earth,’ a Cellist Walks an Ancient Road, Instrument in Tow
summary_short: This documentary opens a window onto a famous Catholic pilgrimage.

headline: Review: On the Run From the Nazis in the Arctic in ‘The 12th Man’
summary_short: Escape is a matter of endurance in this true story of Jan Baalsrud during World War II.

headline: Review: In ‘RBG,’ the Life and Times of a Beloved and Controversial Supreme Court Justice
summary_short: How Ruth Bader Ginsburg became the second woman named to the Supreme Court and the first justice to become a pop-culture phenomenon.

headline: Review: In ‘The Son of Bigfoot,’ a Boy, His Father and a Hairy Situation
summary_short: A boy connects with his long-lost, larger-than-life father in this animated film.

headline: Review: In ‘The Desert Bride,’ a Maid Hits the Road in Argentina
summary_short: A road movie of sorts, the film steers clear of melodrama or sentimentality, but never risks hitting anything.

headline: Review: Drink the Juice, Expel Your Demons in ‘The Cleanse’
summary_short: This comedy about self-help movements embarks on an allegorical journey with only the vaguest notion of a destination.

headline: Review: In ‘The Guardians,’ Trouble on the Home Front in Wartime France
summary_short: Nathalie Baye as a rural matriarch managing the family farm while the men are off fighting in World War I.

headline: Review: A Burglar Breaks Into the Wrong House in ‘Bad Samaritan’
summary_short: David Tennant lets loose — maybe a little too loose — as a serial killer seeking vengeance in Dean Devlin’s thriller.

headline: Review: ‘Becoming Who I Was’ Looks at a Boy’s Days, and His Past Lives
summary_short: The documentary follows a Buddhist boy who has been identified as a rinpoche — a reincarnated centuries-old monk.

headline: Review: In ‘Rogers Park,’ Life and Love in a Chicago Neighborhood
summary_short: Two couples struggle to find serenity as middle age and its multiple discontents come breathing down their necks.

headline: Review: In ‘Ava,’ a Tehran Teenager Fights Oppression
summary_short: Sadaf Foroughi’s debut feature is visually inventive and dramatically bitter.

headline: Review: ‘Duck Butter’ and the 24-Hour ‘for Real’ Relationship
summary_short: Alia Shawkat and Laia Costa star in this charmer about strangers who hook up and try to cram a world of togetherness into a day and night.

headline: Review: ‘The Rachel Divide,’ About Rachel Dolezal, Goes No More Than Skin-Deep
summary_short: The documentary doesn’t figure out how to deal with a woman who essentially owes her fame to the obfuscation of her past.

headline: Review: ‘Supercon’ Cheats Its Audience Out of a Good Heist
summary_short: With unpalatable characters and a crude style, the film makes robbing a comic book convention seem like a bore.

headline: Review: Punk and Futurism Collide in ‘The House of Tomorrow’
summary_short: Peter Livolsi’s painfully quirky tale features two damaged young men — and a woman obsessed with her long-ago mentor, R. Buckminster Fuller.

headline: Review: Zapped by Lightning, a French Teacher Becomes ‘Mrs. Hyde’
summary_short: Isabelle Huppert plays an inept educator who finds new abilities when a laboratory experiment goes awry.

headline: Review: In ‘The Escape of Prisoner 614,’ Tone Escapes as Well
summary_short: A pair of fired deputies set out to retrieve an escaped prisoner and appease a crusty old sheriff, but complications ensue.

display_title: The Test & The Art of Thinking
headline: Review: ‘The Test and the Art of Thinking’ Is About A) The SAT
summary_short: The documentary listens to dozens of student and academics who find that the test, and the ACT, fail to accurately gauge potential or ability.

display_title: In the Last Days of the City
headline: Review: ‘In the Last Days of the City’ Is an Ode to Cairo
summary_short: This movie from the Egyptian director Tamer El Said revolves around a filmmaker at work.

headline: Review: In ‘Modern Life Is Rubbish,’ a Musician Fights Maturity, Again
summary_short: Daniel Jerome Gill’s romantic drama, leaden with Britpop nostalgia, follows some of the most conventional moves of the cinematic playbook.

headline: Review: Halle Berry, Daniel Craig and Los Angeles Tensions in ‘Kings’
summary_short: This film set against the backdrop of the 1992 Los Angeles riots is well-acted across the board.

headline: Review: In ‘Love & Bananas,’ Uncovering the Plight of the Asian Elephant
summary_short: In this personal movie, the actress Ashley Bell embarks on an elephant rescue in Thailand that also reveals the threats to the animal’s survival.

headline: Review: The Flesh Is Willing in ‘Disobedience’
summary_short: Rachel Weisz and Rachel McAdams play former lovers who reunite under the disapproving gaze of a male-dominated religious community.

headline: Review: ‘Let the Sunshine In’ Shows the Complex Radiance of Juliette Binoche
summary_short: Ms. Binoche is an artist looking for love in Claire Denis’s new film.

headline: ‘Avengers: Infinity War’: It’s Marvel’s Universe. We Just Live in It.
summary_short: Infinity? Come on. It’s not even three hours! But there is enough time to get a hunky-Chris showdown (Pratt vs. Hemsworth vs. Evans).

headline: Review: ‘Super Troopers 2’: The Broken Lizard Boys Are Back
summary_short: The eternal adolescents reprise their roles as Vermont state troopers — this time, overseeing an adjustment of United States borders with Canada.

headline: Review: ‘I Feel Pretty’ Doesn’t Even Go Skin Deep
summary_short: In her latest comedy, Amy Schumer plays an insecure woman who, after an accident, decides she’s a knockout. Laughs ensue, but the movie is a bummer.

display_title: Lou Andreas-Salomé, The Audacity to be Free
headline: Review: ‘Lou Andreas-Salomé’ Places a Great Woman in Her Time
summary_short: “Lou Andreas-Salomé, the Audacity to Be Free” casts four actresses to show the evolution of a 19th-century writer with an unusual life.

headline: Review: ‘Kodachrome,’ an Ode to Color Film, Now Streaming Near You
summary_short: Jason Sudeikis and Ed Harris bond over analog media in this drama.

headline: Review: A Paranormal Sleuth Investigates Three ‘Ghost Stories’
summary_short: The film is a nod to vintage British horror anthologies.

headline: Review: ‘After Auschwitz’ Looks at Six Survivors and Their Lives
summary_short: The documentary traces the experiences of six women who settled in the United States after the end of World War II.

headline: Review: In ‘The Devil and Father Amorth,’ a Filmmaker Gets Real
summary_short: How do you go about getting an exorcist? William Friedkin investigates.

headline: Review: In ‘Beyond the Clouds,’ a Brother and Sister Struggle in Mumbai
summary_short: Majid Majidi’s new film aims for neorealism but winds up relying on dynamics that are commonplace, if not outright clichéd.

headline: Review: Fighting to Save Her ‘Little Pink House’
summary_short: Catherine Keener stars in the true story of a woman fighting to keep her house from the clutches of eminent domain.

headline: Review: If You Love Godard, You’ll Hate-Watch ‘Godard Mon Amour’
summary_short: A portrait of a filmmaker in crisis that might have worked better as a comedy sketch.

headline: Review: In ‘This Is Our Land,’ Nationalism in a Small French Town
summary_short: A Marine Le Pen-like politician makes inroads in France in this drama.

headline: Review: A Cinematic Marvel, ‘Zama’ Brilliantly Tackles Colonialism in the New World
summary_short: In Lucrecia Martel’s “Zama,” an 18th-century magistrate in the Americas desperately tries to leave a cruel, cruelly comic world he has helped make.

headline: Review: ‘Grace Jones: Bloodlight and Bami’ Finds the Model, Singer, Actress, Person
summary_short: Grace Jones has always been an iconoclast. But this documentary restores her humanity.

display_title: Jeannette: The Childhood of Joan of Arc
headline: Review: Joan of Arc Is a Young Headbanger in ‘Jeannette’
summary_short: In his latest film, Bruno Dumont presents an idiosyncratic Joan of Arc: one who has visions of the saints and stomps around to heavy electronic music.

headline: Review: Trapped in a Deadly Game of ‘Blumhouse’s Truth or Dare’
summary_short: A demon-driven game causes problems for a group college students in this horror thriller.

headline: Review: In ‘Wildling,’ Bel Powley Finds Her Inner Monster
summary_short: Fritz Böhm’s creature feature is functional but lacks flavor, our critic writes.

headline: Review: ‘An Ordinary Man’ Stars Ben Kingsley as a War Criminal
summary_short: The film follows a general in the former Yugoslavia on the run from international authorities.

headline: Review: ‘Krystal’ Follows a Teenager’s Racing Heart
summary_short: In this comedy, directed by William H. Macy, a teenager with a bad heart falls for a single mother (a recovering addict and a former stripper).

headline: Review: Two Brothers, One Therapist and an ‘Aardvark’
summary_short: Jon Hamm and Zachary Quinto play estranged brothers coping with mental illness in Brian Shoaf’s dramatic comedy.

headline: Review: In ‘The Judge,’ a Middle Eastern Trailblazer Upholds Women’s Rights
summary_short: Erika Cohn’s upbeat documentary profiles the first woman to be appointed to the Middle East’s religious courts.

headline: Review: In ‘Come Sunday,’ Chiwetel Ejiofor Plays a Doubting Bishop
summary_short: The film tells the story of a real-life evangelical bishop who began preaching that even people who hadn’t been “saved” would be spared from hell.

headline: A War Dog Salutes in ‘Sgt. Stubby: An American Hero’
summary_short: This animated film focuses on a dog who helped troops during World War I.

headline: Review: In ‘Submergence,’ a Love Story Sunk by Geopolitics
summary_short: In Wim Wenders’s film, Alicia Vikander and James McAvoy are soul mates who find each other before a plotline involving Somali jihadists separates them.

headline: Review: ‘The Rider’ Is an American Regional Film to Savor
summary_short: This exceptionally sensitive movie set on the Dakota plains features nonprofessional actors playing versions of themselves.

headline: Review: ‘Borg vs. McEnroe’ Revisits an Epic Court Battle
summary_short: A taciturn Swede (you know who) faces a volatile American (you know who) in Janus Metz’s feature about the 1980 Wimbledon final.

headline: Review: ‘Rampage’ Turns to Rubble, Even Before the Mutant Animals Show Up
summary_short: Dwayne Johnson stars in this adaptation of a 1980s arcade game. But will he get a bonus round if he can save Chicago from a giant gorilla named George?

headline: Review: ‘Hitler’s Hollywood’ Unearths the Cinema of the Third Reich
summary_short: The film uses clips to explore the aesthetics, attitudes and messages of German cinema from 1933 to 1945.

headline: Review: In ‘Beirut,’ a War-Torn Backdrop for American Spy Games
summary_short: Jon Hamm plays a former diplomat who returns to Beirut to help rescue a C.I.A. spy in a thriller written by Tony Gilroy (“Bourne”).

headline: Review: In ‘Lean on Pete,’ a Boy’s Survival in the Other America
summary_short: In Andrew Haigh’s heart-heavy drama, a touching Charlie Plummer plays a poor 15-year-old who runs off with a horse named Lean on Pete.

headline: Review: In ‘Good Luck,’ Miners in Serbia and Suriname Share a Cinematic Link
summary_short: Weaving a spiritual conversation with breathtaking camera work among groups of people who will never meet but share desperation, dreams and camaraderie.

headline: Review: In ‘The Endless,’ a U.F.O. Cult Is More Than It Seems
summary_short: In this film from Justin Benson and Aaron Moorhead, two men return to the cult they escaped.

headline: Review: 1920s Australia Is No ‘Sweet Country’ for Aboriginal Australians
summary_short: The movie tracks the fate of an Aboriginal stockman forced to flee after killing a white farmer in self-defense.

headline: Review: The Kids Are All Right in ‘Blockers.’ The Parents Are Dopes.
summary_short: The laughs run hot and (mostly) cold in this comedy about three daughters who set out to lose their virginity and whose parents try to stop them.

headline: Review: In ‘The Miracle Season,’ Moviemakers Spike a Real-Life Volleyball Story
summary_short: From lighting to music cues, “The Miracle Season” never misses a chance to lunge for your tear ducts.

headline: Review: A Surgeon Performs Miracles in Sudan in ‘The Heart of Nuba’
summary_short: The documentary is more about Tom Catena, who has been tending Mother of Mercy Hospital, than the political situation that restricts humanitarian aid.

headline: Review: ‘Spinning Man’ Is Full of Skeptics. Follow Their Lead.
summary_short: This suspense movie, based on George Harrar’s clever novel, struggles to build tension along the way.

headline: Review: ‘Acorn and the Firestorm’ Strives to Revive the Community Organizing Group’s Reputation
summary_short: This documentary from Reuben Atlas and Sam Pollard aims to look at the importance of Acorn before it filed for bankruptcy.

headline: Review: ‘Where Is Kyra?’ Portrays a Descent Into Poverty
summary_short: Michelle Pfeiffer stars in Andrew Dosunmu’s drama, which mixes harsh realism with stylized film techniques.

headline: Review: ‘Big Fish & Begonia’ Animates the Drama of Mortality
summary_short: A mystical being from an underworld takes the form of a red dolphin in this fantasy.

headline: Review: In John Krasinski’s ‘A Quiet Place,’ Silence Means Survival
summary_short: Mr. Krasinski also stars with his real-life wife, Emily Blunt, in this simple yet thrilling creature feature.

headline: Review: ‘Chappaquiddick’ Revisits a Grim ’60s Kennedy Scandal
summary_short: Kate Mara and Jason Clarke star in a sober reconstruction of a fatal car crash in the summer of 1969.

headline: Review: Joaquin Phoenix Is a Melancholy Avenger in ‘You Were Never Really Here’
summary_short: Lynne Ramsay’s grim and grisly excursion into psychological extremity is based on Jonathan Ames’s novella.

display_title: All the Cities of the North
headline: Review: ‘All the Cities of the North’ Explores Architecture and Men
summary_short: The shards of a story in this experimental film initially focus on two men living on a decaying compound.

headline: Review: In ‘Acrimony,’ Taraji P. Henson Endures Marriage and Script Woes
summary_short: The Tyler Perry melodrama follows a woman who undergoes trials brought on by a cheating husband (Lyriq Bent).

headline: Review: Al Pacino’s Journey With Wilde’s ‘Salomé’
summary_short: A story of obsession plays out in “Wilde Salomé” and “Salomé,” as Mr. Pacino veers into Camp.

headline: Review: Al Pacino’s Journey With Wilde’s ‘Salomé’
summary_short: A story of obsession plays out in “Wilde Salomé” and “Salomé,” as Mr. Pacino veers into Camp.

headline: Review: ‘Personal Problems,’ a Look at African-American Life in 1980 New York
summary_short: The brainchild of the writer Ishmael Reed and the director Bill Gunn, this film is an uncategorizable work of art — and an engrossing one.

headline: Review: In ‘Love After Love,’ an Unflinching Look at Extended Grief
summary_short: Russ Harbaugh’s debut feature delivers something rarely seen in American movies: a warts-and-all examination of extended grief.

headline: Review: On Parole and in Love in ‘Outside In’
summary_short: Edie Falco and Jay Duplass connect romantically in this life-after-prison drama that prioritizes patience and pragmatism over passion.

headline: Review: ‘Gemini’ Finds Murder in a Movie-Soaked Los Angeles
summary_short: The director Aaron Katz plays with film noir conventions in this pleasurably drifty, low-wattage mystery.

headline: Review: ‘The Gardener’ Cultivates the Wealth of Nature
summary_short: Frank Cabot’s garden in Quebec is in part an amalgamation of others that inspired him in his travels.

headline: Review: ‘After Louie’ Looks at an Activist Once the Fighting Ends
summary_short: The film, starring Alan Cumming, centers on a 50-something man who lived through the worst years of the AIDS epidemic.

headline: Review: Sharon Stone Stars in ‘All I Wish,’ a Lukewarm Romantic Comedy
summary_short: A fine performance by Ms. Stone is up against a generic screenplay.

headline: Review: Burt Reynolds Confronts His Past in ‘The Last Movie Star’
summary_short: The film effectively allows the ever-assured actor to score a touchdown on an empty field.

headline: Review: ‘The China Hustle’ Warns of Dicey Investments
summary_short: A documentary may be the wrong delivery mechanism for the byzantine exposé that cries out for detailed news reporting.

headline: Review: Two-Stepping to Happiness in ‘Finding Your Feet’
summary_short: Led by a charming pairing of Imelda Staunton and Celia Imrie, this British retiree rom-com delivers exactly what it promises.

headline: Review: Spielberg’s ‘Ready Player One’ Plays the Nostalgia Game
summary_short: The movie, based on Ernest Cline’s best-selling novel, is set in a dystopian future where a virtual video-game reality reigns, and pop-culture callbacks are legion.

headline: Review: ‘The Great Silence,’ a 1968 Spaghetti Western Unchained
summary_short: Klaus Kinski and Jean-Louis Trintignant face off in the snows of Utah in a bloody genre exercise that is only now receiving a proper U.S. release.

headline: Review: In ‘Midnight Sun,’ the Dawn of Romance Can Be Fatal
summary_short: Bella Thorne stars as a teenager with a rare disease who must avoid ultraviolet light — but she isn’t avoiding love. One night, she meets a boy.

headline: Review: Wife Returns in ‘Ismael’s Ghosts.’ Confusion Ensues.
summary_short: In Arnaud Desplechin’s remarkable sprawl of a film, a wife comes back after a 20-year disappearance, adding to an already convoluted situation.

headline: Review: Seeking Justice After a Rape in ‘Beauty and the Dogs’
summary_short: In this film inspired by a true story, the director Kaouther Ben Hania leans hard on official corruption and a bureaucracy dominated by male power.

headline: Review: ‘The Workshop’ Plunges Into a Class Divided
summary_short: This new film from the French director Laurent Cantet follows a diverse group of students enrolled in a summer writing class taught by a famous novelist.

headline: Review: Slaying Monsters (and Avoiding Grief) in ‘I Kill Giants’
summary_short: This magical movie marries adult themes and childlike wonder as a troubled girl embarks on a fantastical quest.

headline: Review: Wes Anderson’s Bleakly Beautiful ‘Isle of Dogs’
summary_short: Set in a fantasy Japan, Mr. Anderson’s new movie tells a heroic story of abandoned dogs, voiced by Bill Murray, Liev Schreiber and others.

headline: Review: ‘Sherlock Gnomes’ and the Search for Better Wordplay
summary_short: This caper, a sequel to “Gnomeo & Juliet,” has a limited universe and possibilities — imagine if “Toy Story” had basically one kind of toy.

headline: Review: In ‘Unsane,’ It’s Not Paranoia if Someone’s After You
summary_short: In his latest, Steven Soderbergh toys with genre and showcases a great, game Ms. Foy in a thriller about a woman trapped in a psychiatric hospital.

headline: Review: ‘Back to Burgundy,’ a Lightheaded Ode to Winemaking
summary_short: In this film from Cédric Klapisch, the prodigal son of a winemaking family returns home.

headline: Review: In ‘What We Started,’ the Back Story Behind the Backbeat
summary_short: In this documentary, the demigods of electronic dance music gush about the genre’s milestones.

headline: Review: ‘Final Portrait’ Watches Giacometti’s Paint Dry
summary_short: The writer James Lord (Armie Hammer) poses for the artist (Geoffrey Rush) in what is essentially a 90-minute conversation.

headline: Review: ‘Summer in the Forest’ Captivates With Questions of Humanity
summary_short: The documentary looks at Jean Vanier, the found of L’Arche, a community for those with developmental disabilities.

headline: Review: ‘A Bag of Marbles,’ a Tale of Brothers Fleeing From Nazis
summary_short: The film follows two brothers as they escape Nazi-occupied Paris to Vichy France, where they are forced to go on the run once more.

headline: Review: ‘Roxanne Roxanne’ Is a Slice of Old-School Hip-Hop Life
summary_short: This film about Roxanne Shante has an intimate indie vibe nicely suited to its subject: rap stardom in the days before hip-hop culture went global.

headline: Review: In ‘Pacific Rim Uprising,’ Scary Monsters and Super Robots
summary_short: Kaiju come back for world domination in this sci-fi sequel.

headline: Review: A Man Confronts a Mountain in ‘Monte’
summary_short: This movie, part of a retrospective of films by the Iranian director Amir Naderi, is another example of his range.

headline: Review: In ‘Keep the Change,’ Two People With Autism Find Love
summary_short: A stubborn thirtysomething sentenced to spend time in an autism support group after an arrest finds romance, in this film starring actors with autism.

headline: Review: Haves and Have-Nots Collide in ‘Us and Them’
summary_short: This film about a financially strapped British threesome in Britain who torment a wealthy family has bags of style and even a few ideas.

headline: Review: Teenage Kicks Go Too Far in ‘Flower’
summary_short: Zoey Deutch gives a magnetic performance as a damaged teenager in this wildly entertaining film.

headline: Review: In ‘Love, Simon,’ a Glossy Teen Romance, the Hero Has a Secret
summary_short: This comedy set in a particularly idyllic Atlanta suburb has a gay love story, a blackmailing weasel and surprising emotional resonance.

headline: Review: ‘Tomb Raider’ and the Perils of Blockbustering
summary_short: This dreary, inept reboot stars a badly misused Alicia Vikander in the Angelina Jolie role.

headline: Review: In ‘Dear Dictator,’ a Despot Does Housework
summary_short: Michael Caine plays an ousted Caribbean general who lands in an American suburb. Katie Holmes also stars.

headline: Review: ‘12 Days’ and the Rights of the Mentally Ill
summary_short: In this lucid documentary, the veteran filmmaker Raymond Depardon explores French law and the care of psychiatric patients.

headline: Review: In ‘Our Blood Is Wine,’ Raising Glasses to Tradition in an Ex-Soviet State
summary_short: A sommelier and a director travel through Georgia learning about an ancient winemaking process and meeting some real stars: the vintners.

headline: Review: In ‘Allure,’ Evan Rachel Wood Is a Friend With a Sinister Side
summary_short: The film, from the brothers Carlos and Jason Sanchez, has echoes of the axiom “hurt people hurt people.”

display_title: No Light and No Land Anywhere
headline: Review: Los Angeles Through a Stranger’s Eyes in ‘No Light and No Land Anywhere’
summary_short: By day, she searches for her estranged father; by night, she experiments with anonymous encounters in this character study by Amber Sealey.

headline: Review: ‘Journey’s End’ Returns a Play About World War I to the Screen
summary_short: This drama is an old-fashioned movie from a well-worn source.

headline: Review: In ‘Ramen Heads,’ a Noodle Chef Gets Tangled Up in His Job
summary_short: This documentary centers on Osamu Tomita, who is famous in Japan for his ramen, and watches him and others preparing the dish for dedicated customers.

headline: Review: ‘Maineland’ Considers America With Help From Chinese Students
summary_short: Miao Wang’s documentary explores an increasingly common cultural exchange between the United States and China.

headline: Review: ‘7 Days in Entebbe’ Revisits a Notorious Hijacking
summary_short: Eddie Marsan and Rosamund Pike are among the stars of this new drama about a 1976 terrorist attack and rescue.

display_title: Eight Hours are Not a Day
headline: Review: ‘Eight Hours Don’t Make a Day,’ Another Fassbinder Masterpiece
summary_short: Rainer Werner Fassbinder’s opus, first shown as a series in 1972 and 1973, is funnier, more humane and more optimistic than anything else in his canon.

headline: Review: The Slapstick Horror of ‘The Death of Stalin’
summary_short: Armando Iannucci’s movie is a very funny comedy about life, death and totalitarianism, and it features a superb Steve Buscemi as Khrushchev.

headline: Review: ‘Hannah’ Presents a Woman Undone
summary_short: Charlotte Rampling is transfixing as a woman suffering for her husband’s crime in this quietly stressful film.

headline: Review: In ‘Claire’s Camera,’ Isabelle Huppert Plays a Cannes Newbie
summary_short: The director Hong Sang-soo shows us the less-than-glamorous side of a famous beach town.

display_title: Leaning Into the Wind: Andy Goldsworthy
headline: Review: In ‘Leaning Into the Wind — Andy Goldsworthy,’ an Artist Grapples (Again) With Time
summary_short: A second documentary about Andy Goldsworthy is concerned with how time changes his art — and him.

headline: Review: ‘The Strangers: Prey at Night’ Delivers on Its Title
summary_short: Review: ‘The Strangers: Prey at Night’ Delivers on Its Title

headline: Review: Meet the Peewee Nihilists of ‘Thoroughbreds’
summary_short: In this misfire, two teenage ciphers watch old movies, plot a crime and peer into the heart of murkiness.

headline: Review: The Caper-Comedy ‘Gringo’ Is Staler Than Yesterday’s Tortillas
summary_short: David Oyelowo plays an innocent who gets played by the likes of Charlize Theron and Joel Edgerton in this Tarantino knockoff.

headline: Review: On the Road for a Last Taste of Freedom in ‘The Leisure Seeker’
summary_short: Helen Mirren and Donald Sutherland star as a couple, facing illnesses, who take their 1975 Winnebago and set out for Key West, Fla.

headline: Review: In ‘The Forgiven,’ Forest Whitaker as Archbishop Desmond Tutu
summary_short: “The Forgiven” is heavy-handed from its opening moments through its end credits.

headline: Review: In ‘Shining Moon,’ Two Gay Chilean Actors Confront the Past
summary_short: This film, from the Chilean director Gustavo Letelier, is oddly enticing in its experimental awkwardness.

headline: Review: ‘Itzhak,’ the Man and the Musician
summary_short: Itzhak Perlman makes beautiful music in this documentary by Alison Chernick.

headline: Review: ‘A Wrinkle in Time’ Gives a Child of the Universe Powerful Friends
summary_short: Ava DuVernay’s faithful adaptation of the children’s science-fiction classic is generous and encouraging.

headline: Review: ‘Red Sparrow’ Has Spies, Lies and Dirty Dancing
summary_short: Jennifer Lawrence stars as a Russian ballerina who becomes an intelligence operative in a lurid, bloody, slickly entertaining thriller.

headline: Review: Cleaning Up Chicago in ‘Death Wish’
summary_short: Eli Roth’s new movie, with Bruce Willis in the lead role, is a misfire that revels in urban paranoia.

headline: In ‘Souvenir,’ a Pâté Factory Worker Finds a Champagne Life
summary_short: Isabelle Huppert plays a woman who turns out to have a past: as a Eurovision singer.

headline: Review: In ‘They Remain,’ Scientists Investigate the Site of a Cult Massacre
summary_short: The past haunts two workers in a remote pocket of woodland, in this lo-fi film from Philip Gelatt.

headline: Review: In ‘Chasing Great,’ the Softer Side of Rugby
summary_short: This film about the New Zealand sports star Richie McCaw’s career mostly hops from triumph to triumph.

display_title: Breaking Point: The War for Democracy in Ukraine
headline: Review: ‘Breaking Point’ Finds Fake News and Real Violence in Ukraine
summary_short: The documentary, directed by Mark Jonathan Harris and Oles Sanin, looks at Russian aggression toward the country, which is struggling to rebuild.

headline: Review: A Young Writer Implodes in ‘The Vanishing of Sidney Hall’
summary_short: Not even a highly competent cast, including Kyle Chandler and Nathan Lane, can save this film from its disastrously fragmented plot.

headline: Review: In ‘Hondros,’ a Tribute to a Bold and Compassionate War Photographer
summary_short: This documentary about the photojournalist Chris Hondros is also a tribute.

headline: Review: A Cover-Up Turns Terrifying in ‘Midnighters’
summary_short: Julius Ramsay’s film is a tight, twisty thriller with horror-movie flourishes.

headline: Review: In ‘Goldstone,’ an Aboriginal Detective Digs Up Corruption
summary_short: This parched Outback western harbors a robust social conscience beneath its hotbed of bribery and sex trafficking.

headline: Review: A Tragic Wig and the Search for Happiness in ‘Oh Lucy!’
summary_short: The writer-director Atsuko Hirayanagi traces the ordinary absurdities of one woman’s life in this against-the-odds charmer.

headline: Review: ‘Submission’ Plunges Into a Campus Sex Scandal
summary_short: Stanley Tucci plays a professor tempted by a student’s writing in this adaptation of Francine Prose’s novel “Blue Angel.”

headline: Review: In ‘Werewolf,’ a Drug-Addicted Couple Struggle to Stay Clean
summary_short: The austere truths of Ashley McKenzie’s drama are bracing.

display_title: Did You Wonder Who Fired the Gun?
headline: Review: ‘Did You Wonder Who Fired the Gun?’ Reckons With White Supremacy
summary_short: A filmmaker investigates a racial murder committed by his great-grandfather in Jim Crow-era Alabama. It’s an intensely, painfully personal project.

headline: Review: ‘El Mar La Mar,’ an Abstract Look at Desert Border Crossings
summary_short: This fascinating experimental documentary concerns migration in the Sonoran Desert.

headline: Review: In ‘The Young Karl Marx,’ a Scruffy Specter Haunts Europe
summary_short: Raoul Peck’s new film is a buddy movie about the founders of Communism.

headline: Review: In ‘The Lodgers,’ Something Wicked This Way Trundles
summary_short: A brother and sister live alone in an eerie ruin that Miss Havisham (and real-estate flippers) would love.

headline: Review: In ‘Annihilation,’ a Heroic Journey into the Alien Shimmer
summary_short: In the new movie from Alex Garland (“Ex Machina”), Natalie Portman plays a biologist who tries to unlock the mysteries of an extraterrestrial whatsit.

headline: Review: In ‘Every Day,’ Each 24 Hours Brings Another Boyfriend
summary_short: The film, based on a novel by David Levithan, is a love story of an unusual sort.

headline: Review: ‘Are We Not Cats’ Offers Hair Balls of a Different Order
summary_short: This peculiar indie pairs a soulful-eyed New York hipster with a soul-music-loving woman. He bites his nails, but she has a more unusual habit.

headline: Review: ‘The Cured,’ in Which Former Zombies Turn to New Terrorism
summary_short: David Freyne’s debut feature, set in Ireland, makes the plight of those who were once undead into a kind of allegory of the Troubles.

headline: Review: An Estonian Folk Tale Unfolds in ‘November’
summary_short: This film from Rainer Sarnet builds a bizarre love story stuffed with supernatural lunacy.

headline: Review: ‘Game Night’ Has a Winning Rachel McAdams and Charades With a Twist
summary_short: A married couple questions reality after their weekly couples game night turns into a kidnapping mystery.

headline: Review: ‘George,’ Like Its Fluxus Subject, Is Playful and Prankish
summary_short: A documentary details the rise of the avant-garde art movement founded by George Maciunas, though Fluxus remains as hard as ever to pin down.

headline: Review: In ‘Western,’ German Workers Fan Tensions in a Bulgarian Town
summary_short: Valeska Grisebach’s film evokes a classic American genre to tease out the contradictions of modern European capitalism.

headline: Review: ‘Early Man’ Is a Very Funny Trip to the Past
summary_short: The latest film from Aardman Animations celebrates the essential silliness of Homo sapiens. There’s soccer, too.

headline: Review: ‘Nostalgia’ Asks Why We Keep Things
summary_short: In Mark Pellington’s film, mourners get a helping hand in parting with cherished objects.

headline: Review: ‘The Boy Downstairs’ Provides a Twist of Fate for Zosia Mamet
summary_short: In this debut feature from the writer and director Sophie Brooks, Ms. Mamet unwittingly moves into the Brooklyn brownstone where her ex lives.

headline: Review: ‘Honor Up’ Offers a Raw View of Gangster Life
summary_short: The filmmaking is point-and-shoot rudimentary, yet this anecdotal movie about drug dealers and their troubles can be oddly persuasive.

headline: Review: A London Night Goes Wrong in ‘The Party’
summary_short: Sally Potter directs a very fine cast in a would-be comedy about a calamitously bad evening.

headline: Review: In ‘The Housemaid,’ Twisted Love and Angry Ghosts in Vietnam
summary_short: Set in 1953, when the country was under French colonial rule, the story takes place on a plantation that harbors shameful secrets — and an apparition.

headline: Review: ‘Double Lover’ Is a Knotty Delight of a Thriller
summary_short: Psychoanalysts play mind games (and more) with a vulnerable young woman in François Ozon’s thriller.

headline: Review: ‘Tehran Taboo’ Exposes Double Standards About Sex in Iran
summary_short: The director Ali Soozandeh uses rotoscoping, a form of animation, in this ensemble piece involving a prostitute, a judge and a musician, among others.

headline: Review: In ‘Golden Exits,’ Ties That Bind (and Cut Too)
summary_short: Alex Ross Perry charts the happiness, misery and profound self-absorption of assorted Brooklynites. It’s funny! (Also sad and squirm-inducing.)

headline: Review: In ‘The Peacemaker,’ a Negotiator Who Is No Idealist
summary_short: A new documentary about Padraig O’Malley, a steely amateur diplomat who has brokered resolutions in Northern Ireland and South Africa.

headline: Review: Finally, the Audience Is ‘Fifty Shades Freed’
summary_short: Ana and Christian tie the knot and settle old scores in this flaccid film.

headline: Review: ‘Seeing Allred’ Watches a Pit-Bull Lawyer at Work
summary_short: The documentary charts Gloria Allred’s history of activism and a few of her current cases.

headline: Review: ‘Permission’ Puts Dan Stevens and Rebecca Hall on the Market
summary_short: A longstanding relationship gets a jolt when a friend of the couple asks a provocative question.

headline: Review: This ‘Peter Rabbit’ Is No Beatrix Potter, but It’s Not All Bad
summary_short: The beloved children’s character wisecracks like Bugs Bunny, with James Corden’s British accent, in this C.G.I.-heavy film directed by Will Gluck.

headline: Review: In ‘Becks,’ a Guitarist With the Blues Returns Home
summary_short: The movie exemplifies how small judgments in pace, performance and soundtrack can transcend modest trappings.

headline: Review: Suicidal Man Seeks Mystery Woman for ‘Entanglement’
summary_short: In this romantic comedy, Thomas Middleditch plays a suicidal man searching for the woman his parents almost adopted. It’s complicated.

headline: Review: ‘The Female Brain’ Flattens the Female Experience
summary_short: Moviegoers get a look at the brain scans of couples as a scientist seeks a theory of gender behavior.

display_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films 2018: Documentary
headline: Review: In the Oscar-Nominated Documentary Shorts, Moving Portraits and Visceral Stories
summary_short: There are plausible rationalizations for why any of this year’s Oscar-nominated documentary shorts might win.

display_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films 2018: Animation
headline: Review: In These Oscar-Nominated Animated Shorts, Riveting Fairy Tales and Kitchen Rot
summary_short: The animated program for the Oscar-nominated shorts includes a film narrated by Kobe Bryant, a Pixar short and a French movie starring frogs.

display_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films 2018: Live Action
headline: Review: In the Oscar-Nominated Live Action Shorts, Four Dramas and a Comedy
summary_short: Topically diverse and politically relevant, the live action shorts program features three based on actual incidents.

headline: Review: In ‘The 15:17 to Paris,’ Real Heroes Portray Their Heroism
summary_short: A foiled terrorist attack inspires an effective, stripped-down film from Clint Eastwood starring three men who helped save the day.

headline: Review: ‘Black Panther’ Shakes Up the Marvel Universe
summary_short: The African superhero gets a movie of his own. Ryan Coogler directs a cast that includes Chadwick Boseman, Michael B. Jordan and Lupita Nyong’o.

headline: Review: ‘Winchester’ Has a Grim Helen Mirren. And a Silly Script.
summary_short: This story centers on an eccentric heiress played by Ms. Mirren. The movie has a vast mansion, a psychologist and, well, you can probably guess the rest.

headline: Review: The Persistence of Abbas Kiarostami’s Vision in ‘24 Frames’
summary_short: For his final movie, Kiarostami added sound and movement to still photographs of lonely, beautiful scenes filled with snow, trees and animals.

display_title: Above & Beyond: Giving Up the Day Job
headline: Review: A Break from Electronic in ‘Above & Beyond Acoustic: Giving Up the Day Job’
summary_short: Slowing down from its dance music mode, the group Above & Beyond chills out on conventional instruments in this documentary.

headline: Review: In ‘Before We Vanish,’ the Aliens Have a Lot of Questions
summary_short: The latest from the Japanese horror master Kiyoshi Kurosawa is a philosophical inquiry as a prelude to extraterrestrial invasion.

headline: Review: ‘Legend of the Mountain,’ a Magical Mystery Marathon in Ancient China
summary_short: Newly restored, King Hu’s 1979 period film follows a scholar deep into the misty countryside.

headline: Review: The Ring Is a Cage in Every Sense in ‘The Cage Fighter’
summary_short: This documentary suggests that boxing-movie clichés may simply be true to life.

headline: Review: Andrea Bocelli, From Cradle to Stage in ‘The Music of Silence’
summary_short: Michael Radford’s film tells a fictionalized version of the life of Andrea Bocelli.

headline: Review: ‘In the Intense Now’ Revisits the Drama of 1968 in France and Beyond
summary_short: João Moreira Salles’s ruminative documentary essay features footage from the era along with personal voice-over narration.

headline: Review: ‘Padmaavat’ and All That Useless Beauty
summary_short: It inspired protests and threats of violence in India, but “Padmaavat” is something of a bore: a 3-D epic with the depth of a children’s pop-up book.

headline: Review: In ‘Have a Nice Day,’ a Follow-the-Money Tale in China
summary_short: This wittily animated feature by Liu Jian works as a gangster thriller and a commentary on modern materialism.

headline: Review: In ‘The Last Family,’ a Polish Artist’s Tragic Home Life
summary_short: The difficult family life of the Polish painter Zdzislaw Beksinski makes for an often funny but also harrowing and heartbreaking film.

headline: Review: In ‘Shot in the Dark,’ Two Things Are Unforgiving: Life and Basketball
summary_short: The documentary, set in Chicago, follows the Orr Academy High School Spartans as they fight for success on and off the court.

headline: Review: ‘West of the Jordan River’ Examines the Mideast Peace Process
summary_short: In this documentary, the Israeli director Amos Gitai describes himself as an archaeologist of Israeli-Palestinian relations.

headline: Review: Finding Unwanted Fame in ‘The Clapper’
summary_short: This misfire from Dito Montiel mashes limp romance and artless satire in a tale of bottom-feeding Hollywood actors.

headline: Review: Boldly Going Toward Independence in ‘Please Stand By’
summary_short: Dakota Fanning plays a young woman with autism and a “Star Trek” fixation.

headline: Review: ‘Maze Runner: The Death Cure,’ an Enjoyably Overstuffed Sequel
summary_short: However silly it may sound, the third “Maze Runner” really moves.

headline: Review: In ‘Forever My Girl,’ a Romance Resumes After a Long Break
summary_short: There are few hard feelings in Bethany Ashton Wolf’s adaptation of a novel by Heidi McLaughlin.

headline: Review: In ‘Den of Thieves,’ Gerard Butler Trails a Former Marine
summary_short: An officer is obsessed with the leader of a group of Marines turned bank robbers in this action flick that is set in Los Angeles.

headline: Review: ‘12 Strong’ Believes in the Brotherhood of Battle
summary_short: Chris Hemsworth stars in this action movie about a Special Forces team on a dangerous mission in Afghanistan right after Sept. 11.

headline: Review: In ‘A Ciambra,’ a Young Roma Boy Comes of Age
summary_short: Italy’s official Oscar entry is a sign that the old neorealist tradition is still alive.

headline: Review: ‘The Banishment,’ a Sophomore Feature Resurrected
summary_short: The second film from the Russian director Andrey Zvyagintsev finally gets a New York run.

headline: Review: ‘Mary and the Witch’s Flower’ Chases a Girl and Her Broomstick
summary_short: A charming children’s entertainment with hints of Miyazaki and “Harry Potter.”

headline: Review: ‘Kangaroo: A Love-Hate Story’ Exposes a Wildlife Massacre
summary_short: The documentary looks at the mass killings of kangaroos for pet-food companies, leather processors and ranchers in Australia.

headline: Review: ‘The Final Year,’ a Countdown for Obama-Era Diplomacy
summary_short: Diplomats travel from one trouble spot to the next in “The Final Year,” a look at the waning days of the Obama administration.

headline: Review: ‘Mama Africa’ Remembers the Life of Miriam Makeba
summary_short: The documentary presents a highlight reel of crucial events from the South African singer and activist’s life.

headline: Review: Nicolas Cage Goes Homicidally Nuts in ‘Mom and Dad’
summary_short: In this morbid satire about parents trying to kill their kids, Mr. Cage has plenty of opportunity to go full him.

headline: Review: In ‘The Road Movie,’ Russian Highways Are the Final Frontier
summary_short: This documentary is compiled entirely from Russian dashboard camera videos.

display_title: Tall: The American Skyscraper and Louis Sullivan
headline: Review: ‘Tall’ Is a Little Movie About How Buildings Got So Big
summary_short: The competing legacies of two pioneering Chicago architects frame a documentary’s exploration of the modern American cityscape.

headline: Review: In ‘Small Town Crime,’ Trouble Is His Business (Natch)
summary_short: John Hawkes stars as a hard-boozing former cop who stumbles into a mystery involving some very young women and some very bad men.

headline: Review: In ‘Beuys,’ a Portrait of the Artist as a Socially Conscious Provocateur
summary_short: A new documentary chronicles the work of the conceptual artist Joseph Beuys and the depression he suffered in the 1950s.

headline: Review: In ‘Proud Mary,’ Taraji P. Henson Is a Hit Woman With a Soft Spot
summary_short: Babak Najafi directed this action thriller that aims to carry on the tradition of films like “Foxy Brown.” Danny Glover also stars.

headline: Review: In ‘Saturday Church,’ Coming of Age, and Coming Out
summary_short: Luka Kain is a find in “Saturday Church,” as a gay teen seeking acceptance and friendship.

headline: Review: In ‘Humor Me,’ a Dose of Borscht Belt for a Midlife Crisis
summary_short: In Sam Hoffman’s directorial debut, a sad-sack played by Jemaine Clement moves in his with his ebullient father, portrayed by Elliott Gould.

headline: Review: A Man and a Woman (and Another Woman) in ‘Lover for a Day’
summary_short: In Philippe Garrel’s drama, a 23-year-old woman moves in with her father and his 23-year-old girlfriend. Complications ensue.

headline: Review: ‘Acts of Violence’ Delivers What Its Title Promises
summary_short: The movie, which stars Bruce Willis and Cole Hauser, is an action thriller that harks back to grindhouse pictures of the ’70s and ’80s.

headline: Review: ‘What Lies Upstream,’ a Broad View of a Chemical Spill
summary_short: This documentary from Cullen Hoback will make you think twice about what’s in your tap water.

headline: Review: In ‘Freak Show,’ the Boy Who Would be Homecoming Queen
summary_short: The film, directed by Trudie Styler, is another high-school tale told in too-broad strokes.

headline: Review: In ‘Bitter Money,’ Documenting China’s Textile Boom
summary_short: The latest film from Wang Bing follows the mass migration to Huzhou during a boom in clothing manufacturing.

headline: Review: Martin Landau and Paul Sorvino in ‘Abe and Phil’s Last Poker Game’
summary_short: The film, about a physician who moves into a nursing home with his wife, is directed by Howard L. Weiner, a neurology professor.

headline: Review: ‘Dim the Fluorescents’ Unites Two Roommates in Art and Commerce
summary_short: In this tragicomedy, an actress and a playwright scrape by with corporate gigs, but set their sights on loftier artistic goals.

headline: Review: In ‘My Art,’ the Artist Laurie Simmons Plays an Artist
summary_short: Ms. Simmons directs and stars in this feature about a woman whose solitude perhaps helps and hinders her creativity.

headline: Review: ‘The Commuter’ Has Panic, Paranoia and Punches. Liam Neeson Too.
summary_short: Our favorite angry-dad action hero gets back to work in Jaume Collet-Serra’s latest film.

headline: Review: Excellence Pursued in ‘Paddington 2’
summary_short: A neighborly bear makes for an adorable sequel.

headline: Review: ‘Vazante’ Revisits Brazil’s History in Black and White
summary_short: Set in 1821, during the slavery era, the film is an austere story about white farmers and enslaved black men, women and children.

headline: Review: In ‘The Insult,’ the Dispute Is Personal. And Political.
summary_short: Lebanon’s energetic Oscar entry is the story of a quarrel that escalates into greater conflict.

headline: Review: ‘In Between’ Tells of Three Women Fighting Patriarchy in Tel Aviv
summary_short: Maysaloun Hamoud’s debut feature is a timely, warm and energetic celebration of friendship.

headline: Review: ‘The Green Fog,’ a Salute to Hitchcock’s San Francisco
summary_short: The documentary is a sort of fast-forward remake of “Vertigo,” built from clips of movies and TV shows shot in the city.

headline: Review: ‘Django’ Distills a Perilous Musical Moment
summary_short: In occupied France, the spotlight falls on a jazz guitar genius trying to escape the Nazis.

headline: Review: ‘Blame’ Conjures ‘Carrie,’ but Without Telekinesis
summary_short: Quinn Shephard stars in her own film, about a troubled high school girl who’s cast as Abigail in “The Crucible” — yet that’s far from her biggest drama.

headline: Review: ‘In the Land of Pomegranates’ Asks if Mideast Peace Is Possible
summary_short: The documentary, directed by Hava Kohav Beller, listens as young Israelis and Palestinians talk to each other about their lives and their land.

headline: Review: In ‘Devil’s Gate,’ Satanic Shenanigans
summary_short: Milo Ventimiglia plays a suspected kidnapper sitting on an evil secret in this horror film.

headline: Review: ‘Dark Meridian’ Is a Crime Thriller Starring New Orleans
summary_short: A detective and a gangster’s son team up in this low-budget movie from Rankin Hickman.

display_title: Anatomy of a Male Ballet Dancer
headline: Review: The Incomplete Vision of ‘Anatomy of a Male Ballet Dancer’
summary_short: This documentary about the dancer Marcelo Gomes was completed before he left American Ballet Theater in December after allegations of sexual misconduct.

display_title: The 19th Annual Animation Show of Shows
headline: Review: Roulette, a Hangman and Singing Fish, in an Animation Fest
summary_short: The 19th annual Animation Show of Shows comes to the Quad Cinema with a wide spectrum of styles and subjects, veterans and newcomers.

display_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool
headline: Review: ‘Film Stars Don’t Die in Liverpool’ Shares a Last-Gasp Romance
summary_short: The movie, adapted from the 1986 memoir by Peter Turner, tracks the final years in the life of the actress Gloria Grahame.

headline: Review: ‘In the Fade’ Is a Tale of Grief and Violence in Modern Germany
summary_short: In Fatih Akin’s new film, Diane Kruger plays a Hamburg woman who fights for justice and sanity after the murder of her husband and son.

display_title: All the Money in the World
headline: Review: Christopher Plummer Dominates ‘All the Money in the World’
summary_short: Mr. Plummer, who replaced Kevin Spacey in the role of J. Paul Getty, is magnetic in the film, which recounts the 1973 kidnapping of his grandson.

headline: Review: Daniel Day-Lewis Sews Up Another Great Performance in ‘Phantom Thread’
summary_short: Paul Thomas Anderson’s latest film is a luxuriant love story set in 1950s London.

headline: Review: The Big and Minor Stakes of ‘Molly’s Game’
summary_short: In Aaron Sorkin’s directorial debut, Jessica Chastain plays a gambling entrepreneur running a high-stakes poker game. Much talking, some walking.

headline: Review: In ‘The Post,’ Democracy Survives the Darkness
summary_short: Steven Spielberg’s film about the Pentagon Papers is a ticktock thriller that pits freedom of the press — and a tough woman — against the White House.

headline: Review: In ‘Happy End,’ Another Unhappy Family From Michael Haneke
summary_short: Isabelle Huppert, Toby Jones and Mathieu Kassovitz make up a remarkable ensemble cast. But “Happy End” belongs to Jean-Louis Trintignant.

headline: Review: In ‘Father Figures,’ Ed Helms and Owen Wilson on a Hunt for Dad
summary_short: This film about two brothers searching for their real father can’t decide whether it’s a gross-out comedy or an uplifting tale of brotherly love.

headline: Review: ‘Bright’ Has Fairies, Orcs, Elves and L.A. Cops, but Little Magic
summary_short: David Ayer’s urban action film is a loud, ungainly hybrid that does not serve police procedurals or fantasy spectaculars very well.

headline: Review: In ‘Downsizing,’ Matt Damon Sweats the Small Stuff
summary_short: Alexander Payne looks at the big picture in his new movie.

headline: Review: ‘Hostiles’ Grapples With the Contradictions of the Western
summary_short: An Army captain escorts an old enemy and a young widow from New Mexico to Montana in Scott Cooper’s violent modern horse opera.

headline: Review: In ‘A German Life,’ Goebbels’s Secretary Explains Her Actions
summary_short: Did Goebbels’s secretary do anything more than type? This documentary lets viewers judge.

headline: Review: A ‘Crooked House’ of Murder and Resentment
summary_short: Glenn Close, Julian Sands, Gillian Anderson and Christina Hendricks make up an all-star roster of suspects in this Agatha Christie adaptation.

headline: Review: ‘Drawing Home’ Sketches the Life of an Artist Couple
summary_short: Catharine and Peter Whyte captured the beauty of the Canadian Rockies in their art and contributed support of all kinds to artists and the Banff community.

display_title: Along With the Gods: The Two Worlds
headline: Review: ‘Along With the Gods’ Is a Fantasy Journey With C.G.I. at Every Turn
summary_short: This delirious fantasy from Kim Yong-hwa, adapted from a web comic, buries story clarity and emotional depth under a mountain of visual pyrotechnics.

headline: Review: In ‘Hangman,’ Al Pacino Trails a Killer With a Unique Vocabulary
summary_short: The detectives in this serial-killer thriller can’t even be bothered to solve the word puzzle.

headline: Review: ‘Pitch Perfect 3’ Keeps the Songs but Loses the Plot
summary_short: The latest entry in this movie series fares best when its director treats it as a fantastical buddy comedy.

headline: Review: In ‘The Greatest Showman,’ a P.T. Barnum Smaller Than Life
summary_short: The film has the ingredients of a splashy good time — the charismatic Hugh Jackman, for one — but it fast becomes a standard-issue holiday biopic.

headline: Review: ‘Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle’ Has Dwayne Johnson as a Nerd
summary_short: The magical game is back, and this time it’s turning geeks into action heroes and jocks into zoologists.

headline: Review: ‘Permanent,’ About the Hairstyle, Falls Flat
summary_short: Rainn Wilson and Patricia Arquette play the parents of a girl who gets the titular treatment in this unsuccessful comedy.

headline: Review: ‘Wormwood’ Confirms That Errol Morris Is Our Great Cinematic Sleuth
summary_short: The American filmmaker chases down clues and tries to exorcise demons as he tackles the biggest case of his career.

headline: Review: ‘The Rape of Recy Taylor’ Takes a Deep Dive Into Systemic Injustice
summary_short: Nancy Buirski’s film is one of multiple layers and marvelous gumption.

headline: Review: In ‘Soufra,’ a Women-Run Food Truck Grows in Lebanon
summary_short: This documentary from Thomas Morgan, about a female entrepreneur establishing a business just south of Beirut, is a stirring tale of empowerment.

headline: Review: ‘Birdboy,’ a Disturbing Animated Feature from Spain
summary_short: The movie has talking animals, but it’s not necessarily for kids.

headline: Review: ‘Ferdinand’ Delivers a Timeless Be-Yourself Message
summary_short: Ferdinand, the picture-book bull that is actually quite tame, gets new life in a computer-animated adaptation from Carlos Saldanha.

headline: Review: A Sci-Fi Thriller, ‘Beyond Skyline’ Is Beyond Ridiculous
summary_short: Liam O’Donnell’s genre-hopping film takes its characters from Los Angeles to Laos, but risks losing its audience along the way.

headline: Review: In ‘Youth,’ the People’s Dance Troupe, in Love and War
summary_short: This decades-spanning melodrama chronicles the rivalries and heartbreaks of a dance troupe in Mao’s China.

headline: Review: ‘Killing for Love’ Revisits a Virginia Murder Case
summary_short: The true-crime documentary lays out a persuasive case for reasonable doubt in the case against Jens Soering, who was convicted, along with his girlfriend.

headline: Review: Layabouts Behind a Wedding Lens in ‘Sundowners’
summary_short: In this droll comedy from Pavan Moondi, a pair of feckless layabouts are assigned to video-record a wedding at a Mexican resort. Mishaps ensue.

headline: Review: Emotional ‘Desolation’ and Woodland Horror
summary_short: This psycho-in-the-woods tale benefits from sensitive writing and organic performances.

headline: Review: The Sidekick as Hero in ‘The Ballad of Lefty Brown’
summary_short: Bill Pullman stars in this Montana-set western, which tips its cowboy hat to classics of the genre.

headline: Review: ‘Star Wars: The Last Jedi’ Embraces the Magic and Mystery
summary_short: With charm and wit, the latest “Star Wars” movie unites the past and present as it looks toward the future.

headline: Review: In ‘Miss Kiet’s Children,’ Refugees Adjust to Dutch Life
summary_short: The documentary by Petra Lataster-Czisch and Peter Lataster follows young students in the classroom but doesn’t examine their lives outside school.

headline: Review: ‘Just Getting Started’ Has Big Names, Not Big Laughs
summary_short: The writer-director Ron Shelton returns to his favorite themes in this comedy starring Morgan Freeman, Tommy Lee Jones and Rene Russo.

headline: Review: ‘Quest’ Is a Moving Portrait of an American Family
summary_short: This documentary from Jonathan Olshefski follows a North Philadelphia family through the Obama years.

headline: Review: The Architecture of Grief and Dread in ‘Foxtrot’
summary_short: In this drama — Israel’s Oscar submission in the foreign-language category — the writer-director Samuel Maoz offers a devastating view of his country.

headline: Review: In ‘Bullet Head,’ Adrien Brody, John Malkovich and an Angry Dog
summary_short: Paul Solet’s endearingly lunkheaded thriller resembles “Reservoir Dogs,” with an actual dog.

headline: Review: In ‘Hollow in the Land,’ a Headstrong Woman’s Search for Answers
summary_short: When the brother of Dianna Agron’s character is accused of murder, it’s up to her to save him and their family reputation.

headline: Review: If It’s Not One Thing, It’s Your Mother in ‘Kaleidoscope’
summary_short: A toxic mother-son bond drives Rupert Jones’s glum British psychodrama.

headline: Review: ‘I, Tonya.’ I, Punching Bag. I, Punch Line.
summary_short: In this winking biopic, Margot Robbie plays the disgraced ice skater Tonya Harding.

headline: Review: ‘Bill Frisell,’ a Winning Portrait of a Very Nice Guitarist
summary_short: The director Emma Franz focuses on a musician who seems to never stop playing, featuring great collaborators of this “no drama” artist.

headline: Review: ‘The Shape of Water’ Is Altogether Wonderful
summary_short: Guillermo del Toro’s latest film is an unlikely and lyrical love story, inspired by “Creature From the Black Lagoon.”

headline: Review: In ‘Loveless,’ a Broken Family and a Lost Nation
summary_short: The director Andrey Zvyagintsev transforms this tale of a missing child into a grim portrait of Russia today.

headline: Review: In ‘The Other Side of Hope,’ an Old-Fashioned Humanist Fable
summary_short: Aki Kaurismaki’s bittersweet tale of displacement and solidarity has the feel (and anti-authoritarian politics) of a 1930s movie.

headline: Review: ‘Shadowman’ Traces the Rise and Fall of an ’80s Artist
summary_short: Richard Hambleton, a peer of Jean-Michel Basquiat and Keith Haring who went underground, was painting right up until his death this fall.

headline: Review: In ‘The Disaster Artist,’ How to Fail at Moviemaking
summary_short: James Franco directs and stars in this fictionalized look at the making of “The Room,” which fans call the worst movie ever made.

headline: Review: The Strange Tale of the ‘Voyeur’ and the Journalist
summary_short: This squirmy documentary follows the celebrated journalist Gay Talese’s infamous investigation of a motel owner who spied on guests.

headline: Review: ‘Wonder Wheel,’ Woody Allen’s Coney Island Memory Palace
summary_short: Kate Winslet plays an unhappily married woman whose affair with a local Romeo is derailed when he falls for her stepdaughter.

headline: Review: In ‘Sins of the Flesh,’ One Prison Replaces Another
summary_short: A drama about a prison escapee in hiding plays out against the backdrop of the 2011 demonstrations in Cairo’s Tahrir Square.

headline: Review: Strong Performances Anchor ‘The Tribes of Palos Verdes’
summary_short: Not even a move to a picture-perfect California paradise can buoy a troubled family.

headline: Review: ‘Rosa Chumbe’ Offers Little Hope for Redemption
summary_short: An alcoholic cop and her pregnant daughter are forced to reckon with their mistakes in this Peruvian drama.

headline: Review: In ‘Love Beats Rhymes,’ a Hip-Hop Artist Transformed by Poetry
summary_short: The rap luminary RZA and the hip-hop musician Azealia Banks team up for a story of rap and poetry, “Love Beats Rhymes.”

headline: Review: ‘Big Time,’ a Portrait of an Architect as Superstar
summary_short: Kaspar Astrup Schröder’s profile of Bjarke Ingels, who designed the new Two World Trade Center and other buildings, doesn’t get far below the surface.

headline: Review: In ‘32 Pills,’ a Filmmaker Investigates Her Sister’s Death
summary_short: Hope Litoff’s documentary becomes more voyeuristically gripping as it progresses.

headline: Review: ‘The Dancer,’ a Glum Biopic for a Dynamic Innovator
summary_short: The film, directed by Stéphanie Di Giusto, seems genuinely hostile to its subject, the dancer Loïe Fuller, whose real-life accomplishments deserve better.

headline: Review: ‘The New Radical’ Asks, Is It O.K. to Build Your Own Gun?
summary_short: The documentary follows Cody Wilson, who published plans to create a gun using a 3-D printer.

headline: Review: ‘Naples ’44’ Chronicles Life During Wartime
summary_short: Taken from a British intelligence officer’s memoir, and narrated by Benedict Cumberbatch, this film paints a portrait of the occupied city.

headline: Review: ‘Bombshell’ Tells the Amazing Story of Hedy Lamarr, the Star and Inventor
summary_short: In this diverting documentary, Alexandra Dean tells the life story of Hedy Lamarr, a scandalous woman turned star and inventor.

headline: Review: ‘Eric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars,’ of Triumphs and Tragedies
summary_short: A documentary on the life of Eric Clapton is candid on the rock legend’s struggles with addiction.

headline: Review: ‘Cuba and the Cameraman’ Lavishes Love on a Country … and Castro
summary_short: The filmmaker Jon Alpert has been visiting and documenting Cuba for 45 years. His new movie looks back fondly at its people and its leader.

headline: Review: ‘Al Di Qua,’ Homelessness Through an Artsy Filter
summary_short: In this film, Turin’s poorest tell their stories to the camera.

headline: Review: A Boy’s Own Desire in ‘Call Me by Your Name’
summary_short: In the latest movie from the Italian director Luca Guadagnino (“I Am Love”), Armie Hammer plays a visiting student who falls for his host’s teenage son.

headline: Review: ‘Darkest Hour,’ or the Great Man Theory of History (and Acting)
summary_short: Gary Oldman plays Winston Churchill in Joe Wright’s drama about the early days of World War II.

headline: Review: In ‘Brimstone & Glory,’ Passions Blaze at a Fireworks Festival
summary_short: The director Viktor Jakovleski’s movie is a vehicle for cinematographic derring-do.

headline: Review: ‘Coco’ Brings the Pixar Touch to Death
summary_short: The movie delivers moments of cinematic rigor and playful pop-culture erudition. And though it deals with the afterlife, don’t let that scare you.

headline: Review: In ‘The Man Who Invented Christmas,’ Dickens as a Secret Documentarian
summary_short: This drama purports that Charles Dickens took inspiration for his fictional characters from real-life encounters.

headline: Review: In ‘Mr. Roosevelt,’ an Ailing Cat and a Comedian in Crisis
summary_short: Noël Wells wrote, directed and stars in this film about a young woman who returns to her former home and discovers much has changed.

headline: Review: ‘Mudbound’ Is a Racial Epic Tuned to Black Lives, and White Guilt
summary_short: Dee Rees’s new film illuminates the daily cruelties in post-World War II Mississippi.

display_title: Jim & Andy: The Great Beyond - Featuring a Very Special, Contractually Obligated Mention of Tony Clifton
headline: Review: ‘Jim & Andy,’ When Carrey Became Kaufman
summary_short: In his documentary about Jim Carrey, Andy Kaufman and the making of “Man on the Moon,” the director Chris Smith finds multiple realities and laughs.

headline: Review: In ‘The Breadwinner,’ a Girl Bravely Provides for Her Family
summary_short: The children in this animated film based on a novel by Deborah Ellis navigate life under the Taliban.

headline: Review: In ‘Wonder,’ a Not-So-Ordinary Boy Makes His Way
summary_short: Auggie, the little boy in this smart and warmhearted family film, is inspirational in his differences.

headline: Review: A Small-Town Murder Ignites ‘Sweet Virginia’
summary_short: Set in a remote Alaskan valley, the film is a quiet knife-twister in which atmosphere and performance are everything.

headline: Review: ‘Big Sonia’ Honors a Holocaust Survivor
summary_short: Sonia Warshawski, the owner of a tailor shop in a deserted mall, and also a survivor of the Holocaust, is a powerful documentary subject.

display_title: On the Beach at Night Alone
headline: Review: ‘On the Beach at Night Alone’ Zooms in on a Love Affair
summary_short: Kim Min-hee stars in a new film from the prolific South Korean director Hong Sang-soo. The movie has been seen as based partly on their affair.

headline: Review: In ‘Porto,’ a Night of Bliss and Heartbreak
summary_short: In one of the last film roles before his death, Anton Yelchin stars in this first narrative feature from Gabe Klinger.

headline: Review: ‘Wet Woman in the Wind’ Is a Queasy Sex Romp
summary_short: Let’s make no bones about it: This film, part of a project to reboot a Japanese soft-core genre, is designed to appeal to male prurient interest.

headline: Review: In ‘Roman J. Israel, Esq.,’ Denzel Washington as a Lawyer Out of His Element
summary_short: Dan Gilroy’s new film about a socially awkward jurist misfires when it appoints him as a sort of angelic figure.

headline: Review: ‘Cook Off!’ Gives Chefs the ‘Best in Show’ Treatment
summary_short: This mockumentary about a cooking competition features Melissa McCarthy but is being released 10 years after it was first shown at a comedy festival.

headline: Review: ‘A Fantastic Woman’ Lives Up to Its Title, in More Ways Than One
summary_short: Facing a lover’s death and a society’s intolerance, in a film by Sebastián Lelio.

headline: Review: ‘Rebels on Pointe,’ and in Tutus
summary_short: The Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo meld technique with comedy, and tour more than two-thirds of the years

headline: Review: ‘Justice League,’ Better Than the Last One!
summary_short: In this superhero jamboree, the Flash, Aquaman and Cyborg sign on with the DC Comics team leaders Batman and Wonder Woman. (Psst … where’s Superman?)

headline: Review: In ‘Song of Granite,’ Fragments of an Irish Folk Singer’s Life
summary_short: This biography of the singer Joe Heaney seems uncertain of what made him tick.

headline: Review: ‘Santa & Andrés’ Chooses Friendship Over Politics
summary_short: A loyal Communist worker and a dissident gay writer become unlikely friends in this touching Cuban drama.

headline: Review: ‘I Remember You’ Is a Piercing Horror Film From Iceland
summary_short: The director Oskar Thor Axelsson prefers mood and compelling human conflict over copious gore to deliver chills. The result is effective.

headline: Review: In ‘Bitch,’ a Desperate Housewife Finds Her Bark
summary_short: Jason Ritter plays a husband whose wife goes to the dogs in this feminist horror-comedy.

display_title: Window Horses: The Poetic Persian Epiphany of Rosie Ming
headline: Review: ‘Window Horses’ Animates a Young Poet’s Self-Discovery
