summary_short: Ann Marie Fleming’s film explores the passions of a sheltered poet who travels to Shiraz, Iran, for a poetry festival.

headline: Review: In ‘Daddy’s Home 2,’ Father Doesn’t Know Best
summary_short: Mel Gibson gets off lightly as a crass paterfamilias in this comedy sequel to the hit starring Will Ferrell and Mark Wahlberg.

headline: Review: In ‘Thelma,’ a Woman in Love Can Burn Down the World
summary_short: In Joachim Trier’s sly psychological thriller “Thelma,” a child-woman finds love and discovers that behaving like a good girl can be a very bad idea.

headline: Review: Reality Bites in ‘Flesh and Blood’
summary_short: The actor and director Mark Webber portrays a former addict newly released from prison and returning home to reconnect with family.

headline: Review: ‘Intent to Destroy’ Shows That the Armenian Past Is Not Over
summary_short: This documentary, directed by Joe Berlinger, explores the Armenian genocide through old footage of survivors and insights from historians.

headline: Review: ‘No Stone Unturned’ Explores an Attack in Northern Ireland
summary_short: Why did a massacre in a Northern Ireland pub go unsolved for 20 years? The documentary filmmaker Alex Gibney searches for answers.

headline: Review: A Virus Creates ‘Mayhem’ Among Backstabbing Lawyers
summary_short: “Mayhem,” featuring the “Walking Dead” actor Steven Yeun, embraces its pulpy title with fighting-and-fornicating glee.

headline: Review: ‘Destination Unknown,’ Nazi Camps Through the Eyes of Survivors
summary_short: Horror, sadness and a note of hope characterize the stories of 12 people who lived through the Nazi camps.

headline: Review: On Violence and the Pain of Others in ‘Three Billboards’
summary_short: A ferocious Frances McDormand plays a grieving mother seeking justice in Martin McDonagh’s movie, which mixes tears and tragedy with corrosive laughs.

headline: Review: An All-Star ‘Murder on the Orient Express’ With Few Surprises
summary_short: Kenneth Branagh assembles Judi Dench, Johnny Depp, Michelle Pfeiffer and others for his film remake of Agatha Christie’s mystery novel.

headline: Review: ‘Hello Again,’ a Movie Musical Ode to Love and Lust Over Decades
summary_short: This film from Tom Gustafson, based on a 1993 Off Broadway show, has a formidable cast of Broadway names but wants for dramatic traction.

headline: Review: ‘Most Beautiful Island,’ an Immigrant’s New York Nightmare
summary_short: This suspense film, about a woman entering a rabbit hole of urban peril, is an effective writing-directing debut for Ana Asensio, who also stars.

headline: Review: ‘LBJ’ Hides Its Light Under a Bushel of Makeup
summary_short: Woody Harrelson swaggers through this movie, which tries to track the coming into consciousness of Lyndon B. Johnson.

headline: Review: ‘Along for the Ride,’ an Artist Through the Eyes of an Assistant
summary_short: Dennis Hopper’s life could be seen as a wild ride, on and off the screen. Someone who was by Hopper’s side interprets his story.

headline: Review: ‘My Friend Dahmer,’ the Boy Who Became a Cannibal
summary_short: The story of the making of a monster.

headline: Review: ‘A Gray State,’ Behind a Filmmaker’s Madness
summary_short: Erik Nelson’s documentary centers on the aspiring filmmaker David Crowley, whose violent death became a cause for conspiracy theorists.

headline: Review: In ‘Wait for Your Laugh’ and ‘Gilbert,’ Comedians Work Hard
summary_short: These documentaries go behind the scenes with their well-known subjects, Rose Marie and Gilbert Gottfried.

headline: Review: In ‘Wait for Your Laugh’ and ‘Gilbert,’ Comedians Work Hard
summary_short: These documentaries go behind the scenes with their well-known subjects, Rose Marie and Gilbert Gottfried.

headline: Review: Bad Grandmoms Show Up for ‘A Bad Moms Christmas’
summary_short: Christine Baranski, Cheryl Hines and Susan Sarandon join the cast for a sequel to “Bad Moms.”

headline: Review: Sorcery and Revenge Fuel ‘Blade of the Immortal’
summary_short: A brokenhearted girl and an undying samurai team up in Takashi Miike’s film.

headline: Review: In ‘11/8/16,’ Looking at Election Day, After the Race Is Run
summary_short: The documentary followed more than 16 people to the polls on Election Day to learn about their thoughts and feelings on the candidates.

headline: Review: ‘It Happened in L.A.,’ All That Questing After Love
summary_short: This ensemble comedy from Michelle Morgan concerns one woman who exits a relationship, and another who seeks one. Their city only complicates matters.

headline: Review: ‘Dream Boat’ Documents Cruising on the High Seas
summary_short: On a luxury cruise for gay men, passengers enjoy lively themed parties and activities as they explore what this inclusive experience means to them.

headline: Review: In ‘No Dress Code Required,’ a Gay Couple’s Mexicali Blues
summary_short: Cristina Herrera Borquez’s documentary follows Victor Aguirre and Fernando Urias in their bureaucratic battle to be legally married.

headline: Review: ‘Last Flag Flying’ Is a Starry, Somber and Comic War Movie
summary_short: Three Vietnam vets — played by Steve Carell, Bryan Cranston and Laurence Fishburne — reunite during the Iraq war to accomplish a grim mission.

headline: Review: ‘Thor: Ragnarok,’ of Gods, Monsters and Silly Jokes
summary_short: In the newest, loosest, goofiest and funniest Thor blowout, Chris Hemsworth’s superhero chillaxes with the Hulk and takes a punch from a Valkyrie.

headline: Review: Greta Gerwig’s ‘Lady Bird’ Is Big-Screen Perfection
summary_short: Saoirse Ronan plays a high school senior who insists on asserting her individuality, and it makes for a thrilling film.

headline: Review: ‘The Light of the Moon’ and the Trauma of Rape
summary_short: Stephanie Beatriz plays a young woman who learns to survive after a night out ends in a brutal attack in this drama from Jessica M. Thompson.

headline: Review: In ‘1945,’ Hungarian Villagers Are Forced to Revisit Wartime Sins
summary_short: Ferenc Torok’s lean feature is a Holocaust film built, consciously or not, on a reversal of the tropes of the western.

headline: Review: ‘Frank Serpico’ Updates the Story of the Man Behind a Classic Movie
summary_short: The real Frank Serpico proves to be a compelling figure in a documentary that picks up where the classic Hollywood film left off.

headline: Review: ‘Bill Nye: Science Guy,’ a Portrait of a Fighter for Facts
summary_short: This revealing documentary follows Mr. Nye as he crusades on behalf of space exploration and against creationists and climate-change deniers.

headline: Review: In ‘Félicité,’ a Mother Scrambles to Save Her Son
summary_short: Set in the Democratic Republic of Congo, this film resists the race-against-the-clock trap, instead bringing several illuminating, moving surprises.

headline: Review: ‘The Square’ Takes Aim at Art, Sex, Money and More
summary_short: This Swedish satire from Ruben Ostlund, the director of “Force Majeure,” won the top prize at Cannes.

headline: Review: Glib Laughs and Race Hate in ‘Suburbicon’
summary_short: George Clooney stays off camera to direct Matt Damon and Julianne Moore in a caustic comedy about the good old American days of fear, hate and rage.

headline: Review: Lena Olin Is Fierce as a Suicidal Poet in ‘Maya Dardel’
summary_short: A character who wants to play with power in a movie that reeks of scholarly pretension.

headline: Review: Two Unlikely Roommates Share Heartbreak in ‘Crash Pad’
summary_short: A slacker, his lover and his lover’s husband make a sticky love triangle in this awkward comedy.

headline: Review: ‘Novitiate’ Shares a Young Nun’s Emotional Story
summary_short: A novice struggles with her own faith in a changing church in this film, written and directed by Maggie Betts.

headline: Review: ‘Mully’ Is a Man Dedicated to Saving Kenya’s Orphans
summary_short: A documentary looks at Charles Mully, who gave up great wealth to aid the poor and homeless in his country.

headline: Review: In ‘All I See Is You,’ Sight Is Restored and a Marriage Rocked
summary_short: This psychodrama from Marc Forster stars Blake Lively and Jason Clarke as a seemingly happy married couple.

headline: Review: In ‘Thank You for Your Service,’ the War at Home
summary_short: The film, from the screenwriter of “American Sniper,” is an earnest and powerful drama about Iraq veterans returning to Kansas.

headline: Review: ‘The Divine Order’ Recalls the Fight for Women’s Suffrage in Switzerland
summary_short: Set in 1971, Petra Volpe’s film takes a middlebrow, mildly rollicking approach toward a serious subject.

headline: Review: In Folsom State Prison, ‘The Work’ Sets You Free
summary_short: The film documents four days of punishing group therapy in prison.

display_title: Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold
headline: Review: A ‘Joan Didion’ Portrait, From an Intimate Source
summary_short: This documentary is directed by Griffin Dunne, Ms. Didion’s nephew, a relationship that limits the movie in certain ways, but opens it up in others.

headline: Review: Love Is Wild, if Not Pretty, in ‘God’s Own Country’
summary_short: This feature debut of the writer and director Francis Lee is a bracing, sometimes brutal movie.

headline: Review: In ‘Geostorm,’ Gerard Butler (and His Stubble) Save the Planet
summary_short: In this action film, the world is threatened by a space-based weather-control system armed with ice, fire, hail and heavy rain.

display_title: Tyler Perry's Boo 2! A Madea Halloween
headline: Review: A Case of Déjà Vu in ‘Tyler Perry’s Boo 2! A Madea Halloween’
summary_short: In this sequel that feels like a remake, all prospects for amusement are never even vaguely realized.

headline: Review: ‘BPM (Beats Per Minute)’ Captures the Fierce AIDS Fight
summary_short: This passionate historical drama from Robin Campillo follows young French activists through an emotional battle for respect and care.

headline: Review: ‘Wonderstruck,’ Todd Haynes’s Imitations of Life
summary_short: Mr. Haynes’s lovely adaptation of Brian Selznick’s book centers on a girl in the 1920s and a boy in the ’70s whose lives are mysteriously connected.

headline: Review: ‘Only the Brave’ Is an Inspiring Tale of Firefighter Sacrifice
summary_short: This action drama from Joseph Kosinski — about the Granite Mountain Hotshots of Prescott, Ariz. — offers some real feeling under a schematic surface.

headline: Review: Uncovering a Displaced Family’s Past in ‘Aida’s Secrets’
summary_short: This documentary follows Izak Szewelewicz, who was sent to Israel as a toddler after World War II, on a search for the brother he didn’t know he had.

headline: Review: ‘The Snowman’ Is a Thrill-Free Thriller Tied in Knots
summary_short: Michael Fassbender and other talented people wander through this leaden mess.

display_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
headline: Review: ‘The Killing of a Sacred Deer’ Depicts Familiar Torment
summary_short: Yorgos Lanthimos’s follow-up to “The Lobster” is a family drama, starring Colin Farrell and Nicole Kidman, that doesn’t reach the same imaginative peaks of his earlier films.

headline: Review: In ‘Tragedy Girls,’ Teenagers Terrorize (and Tweet)
summary_short: In this slasher comedy, two high school social media stars find that murder is the best way to drum up followers for their online horror brand.

headline: Review: ‘One of Us,’ a Portrait of Starting a New Life
summary_short: This documentary, directed by Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady, follows three ultra-Orthodox Jews who have left the Hasidic community.

headline: Review: ‘Tempestad’ Peers Into Mexico’s Horrific Legal System
summary_short: The documentary listens to the stories of two women tormented by Mexican law enforcement and criminal gangs.

headline: Review: In ‘Dealt,’ a Magician Never Shows His Hand (Until He Does)
summary_short: This documentary focuses on the hyperkinetic card magician Richard Turner.

headline: Review: Secrets and Lies in ‘Never Here’
summary_short: This film, which features Sam Shepard in his final, all-too-brief screen role, plays more like an experimental art project.

headline: Review: Braving Foot Rot and Fire Ants in the Amazon ‘Jungle’
summary_short: Daniel Radcliffe suffers for his art in this true-life survival tale about the Israeli adventurer Yossi Ghinsberg.

headline: Review: ‘Jane’ Is an Absorbing Trip Into the Wild With Jane Goodall
summary_short: Brett Morgen’s documentary tells her story through footage of Ms. Goodall’s interactions with chimpanzees in what is now Tanzania.

headline: Review: ‘Liberation Day,’ Rocking in Pyongyang With Laibach
summary_short: They’re members of a Slovenian band, and they don’t like to reveal too much, even in a documentary.

headline: Review: The Crushed Romanticism of Philippe Garrel’s ‘L’Enfant Secret’
summary_short: A film that opened in Paris in 1979 finally surfaces in the United States.

headline: Review: With ‘The Paris Opera,’ a Peek Behind the Curtain
summary_short: At its most fun, this documentary functions as a stealth backstage chronicle.

display_title: Professor Marston and the Wonder Women
headline: Review: ‘Professor Marston,’ With Kinks! Pleasures! Female Power!
summary_short: In “Professor Marston and the Wonder Women,” the writer-director Angela Robinson tells a knotty story with wit, sympathy and economy.

headline: Review: Reliving Delicious Terror in ‘78/52: Hitchcock’s Shower Scene’
summary_short: A documentary by Alexandre O. Philippe finds plenty to examine in one of the most memorable scenes in American film.

headline: Review: Two Hoarders Clean House in ‘Thy Father’s Chair’
summary_short: The mess that two Brooklyn brothers make of their house in this documentary is unholy in several senses of the term.

headline: Review: Ai Weiwei’s ‘Human Flow’ Tracks the Global Migrant Crisis
summary_short: A documentary from an artist who wants to take viewers beyond the headlines and the images on the nightly news.

headline: Review: In ‘Marshall,’ a Legal Pioneer Gives History a Shove
summary_short: Reginald Hudlin’s movie about the crusading lawyer and Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall smartly keeps the focus tight.

headline: Review: ‘Te Ata’ Shares a Heroic Story of a Chickasaw Ambassador
summary_short: A biopic about the rise of a Native American performer who overcame discriminatory laws to perform on Broadway and in the White House.

headline: Review: Jackie Chan Seeks Vengeance in ‘The Foreigner’
summary_short: He plays an aggrieved father facing off against Pierce Brosnan, who plays a character with possible links to the I.R.A.

headline: Review: In ‘For Ahkeem,’ a Last Option for a Troubled Teenager
summary_short: A documentary observes a St. Louis student facing a bleak future if she can’t graduate from an alternative school.

headline: Review: ‘Tom of Finland’ Is a Portrait of a Boundary-Pushing Artist
summary_short: Dome Karukoski’s biopic about the Finnish illustrator takes his life and reduces it to check marks on a list.

headline: Review: A Cheery Portrait of Severe Disability in ‘Breathe’
summary_short: The disability-rights pioneer Robin Cavendish is given an upbeat biopic in “Breathe,” starring Andrew Garfield and Claire Foy.

headline: Review: In ‘The Departure,’ Watching Over Those Who Flirt With Death
summary_short: This documentary follows a Buddhist priest who counsels those who are in danger of committing suicide.

headline: Review: Dead Again … and Again in ‘Happy Death Day’
summary_short: A mean coed relives her own murder multiple times in this snappy horror-comedy.

headline: Review: ‘Diamond Island,’ a Gentle Look at Teenagers in a Changing Land
summary_short: The drama, directed by Davy Chou, is set in Cambodia and follows a group of young men as they work during the day and search for love at night.

headline: Review: Adam Sandler Is a Revelation in ‘The Meyerowitz Stories’
summary_short: A career high, and not just for this film’s writer and director, Noah Baumbach.

headline: Review: ‘Goodbye Christopher Robin’ Unspools a Difficult Childhood
summary_short: Christopher Robin is more of a marketable commodity than a beloved son in this film by Simon Curtis.

headline: Review: In ‘The Florida Project,’ Enchantment in a Shabby Motel
summary_short: Sean Baker’s new film is a tender and terrifying tale of young children at risk as they run free in the Sunshine State.

headline: Review: Agnès Varda and JR Travel in the Present, Glancing at the Past
summary_short: Ms. Varda’s new documentary is a testament to her curious, generous, democratic spirit.

headline: Review: ‘Brawl in Cell Block 99’ Features a Revelatory Vince Vaughn
summary_short: Mr. Vaughn plays a reluctant avenger in this vicious thriller from the director of “Bone Tomahawk.”

headline: Review: Paul Farmer Works to Heal Haiti in ‘Bending the Arc’
summary_short: This feel-good documentary dives into global health care with the same optimism as its subjects, two founders of Partners in Health.

headline: Review: ‘So B. It’ Has Pluck, Charm and a Muddy Message About Disability
summary_short: This family film follows a precocious 12-year-old on a solo adventure. But its treatment of her mother’s disability ultimately feels instrumental.

display_title: Take Every Wave: The Life of Laird Hamilton
headline: Review: A Daredevil Optimist in ‘Take Every Wave’
summary_short: This documentary about Laird Hamilton, conqueror of big waves, stirs up most of its sporadic excitement with its surfing footage.

headline: Review: ‘Una’ Examines an Abuser and His Victim
summary_short: Rooney Mara and Ben Mendelsohn deliver unflinching performances in “Una,” an adaptation of David Harrower’s provocative play “Blackbird.”

display_title: The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson
headline: Review: ‘The Death and Life of Marsha P. Johnson’ Explores a Mystery
summary_short: The documentary, by David France, looks at the death of the transgender activist. Police say it was suicide; friends suspect it was murder.

headline: Review: Love in a Cold Climate in ‘The Mountain Between Us’
summary_short: Idris Elba and Kate Winslet crash into a mountain — and each other — in this drama.

headline: Review: In ‘Walking Out,’ Two Men Go Hunting; Who Knows Who’ll Come Back
summary_short: The film follows a father and son who trek into the Montana wilderness, only to encounter danger.

headline: Review: ‘Paradise,’ a Holocaust Drama in Black and White
summary_short: The film is strikingly shot, but ultimately seems confused about whose story it’s telling or to what end.

headline: ‘Overdrive,’ a Car Thief Movie That Could Use a Script Tuneup
summary_short: Scott Eastwood and Freddie Thorp star as brothers and car thieves in this action film.

headline: Review: In the Documentary ‘Dina,’ a Differently Abled Love Story
summary_short: An intimate, affecting film about a couple with autism, as they plan their wedding.

headline: Review: ‘The Osiris Child’ Has It All, and Then Some
summary_short: Shane Abbess’s dystopian opus has ambition and literary pretensions to spare, but underneath its overstuffed surface is a bracing bravado.

headline: Review: ‘Chavela’ Recalls the Life of the Ranchera Singer Chavela Vargas
summary_short: The documentary about the singer Chavela Vargas provides a biography, but doesn’t give a strong sense of the musician’s power.

headline: Review: In ‘Blade Runner 2049,’ Hunting Replicants Amid Strangeness
summary_short: The director Denis Villeneuve tries to both honor Ridley Scott’s 1982 dystopian classic and to slip free of its considerable shadow.

headline: Review: Why the New ‘Flatliners’ Is Just ‘Meh’
summary_short: The original starred Julia Roberts, Kiefer Sutherland and Kevin Bacon, among others. The new one has Ellen Page and some horror movie tricks.

headline: Review: A Cranky Loner Faces Mortality in ‘Lucky’
summary_short: In one of his last roles, Harry Dean Stanton shines as a cantankerous old man.

headline: Review: Seeking Connection in a Busy Town in ‘Autumn, Autumn’
summary_short: This South Korean film follows lonely characters in a resort town.

headline: Review: ‘Let’s Play Two’ Takes Pearl Jam Out to the Ball Game
summary_short: Blending concert film and sports diary, Danny Clinch chronicles Pearl Jam’s pair of shows at Wrigley Field during the Cubs’ championship season.

headline: Review: ‘American Made’ Has Tom Cruise. And Lies, Spies and Coke.
summary_short: Mr. Cruise plays a real-life pilot turned smuggler who worked for the C.I.A., in Doug Liman’s new movie.

display_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House
headline: Review: In ‘Mark Felt,’ Liam Neeson Is the Man Known as Deep Throat
summary_short: Peter Landesman’s accidentally timely Watergate procedural has men in suits fighting for the independence of the F.B.I.

headline: Review: A Violent Accident Rocks a Friendship in ‘Super Dark Times’
summary_short: Kevin Phillips’s direction and fine acting from the cast elevate this tale centered on two high schoolers coping with tragedy.

headline: Review: In ‘Realive,’ a Man Is Reanimated in 2084
summary_short: This above-average science-fiction film, written and directed by Mateo Gil, plays like a “Black Mirror” episode combined with a solemn love story.

headline: Review: In ‘Different Flowers,’ a Runaway Bride Gets Help From Her Sister
summary_short: The two siblings get on each other’s nerves and in each other’s business.

headline: Review: Winning Her Back on Deadline in ‘Literally, Right Before Aaron’
summary_short: In this disjointed rom-com, Justin Long plays a man invited to the wedding of his former paramour. He’s not going easily.

headline: Review: An Inheritance Is Threatened in ‘Abundant Acreage Available’
summary_short: Amy Ryan and Terry Kinney are siblings at the center of a land dispute in this film from Angus MacLachlan.

display_title: The Untold Tales of Armistead Maupin
headline: Review: In ‘The Untold Tales of Armistead Maupin,’ a Portrait of a Gifted Writer
summary_short: The film, directed by Jennifer M. Kroot, illustrates how the novelist’s gay experience informed his art.

headline: Review: ‘Blood Stripe’ Finds a Woman Back From War, and Still Fighting
summary_short: A former Marine returns home and battles with post-traumatic stress in this film.

headline: Review: Robert Redford and Jane Fonda Are Neighbors With Benefits in ‘Our Souls at Night’
summary_short: This small-town romance was adapted from the novel by Kent Haruf.

headline: Review: ‘Bugs’ Is a Culinary Adventure. Insects Never Looked so Yummy.
summary_short: Ben Reade and Josh Evans travel the world to visit cultures where insects are prepared as food.

headline: Review: In ‘I Am Another You,’ Eating From a Garbage Can for Her Art
summary_short: Nanfu Wang’s documentary asks if homelessness can be a form of freedom.

display_title: Clive Davis: The Soundtrack of Our Lives
headline: Review: In ‘Clive Davis,’ the Evolution of a Music Mogul
summary_short: The documentary “The Soundtrack of Our Lives” is a valedictory for Mr. Davis, the record executive whose radio acumen is industry legend.

headline: Review: Advantage, Bobby, but Game, Set, Match, Billie Jean in ‘Battle of the Sexes’
summary_short: Emma Stone plays Billie Jean King and Steve Carell plays Bobby Riggs in a movie about the 1973 tennis match that became a referendum on equality.

headline: Review: ‘The Force’ Follows the Oakland Police From Crisis to Crisis
